{{Use British English|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{redirect|2009 G20 protests|the protests that occurred around the September 2009 summit in Pittsburgh|2009 G20 Pittsburgh summit}} {{Infobox news event |image=[[File:G20 crowd.jpg|300px]] |caption= |date= 1 and 2 April 2009 |time= |place= [[City of London]], England|first reporter= |filmed by= |reported injuries= Over 180 protesters made formal complaints of injuries.<ref>Lyall, Sarah. [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/31/world/europe/31police.html?pagewanted=all Critics Assail British Police for Harsh Tactics During the G-20 Summit Meeting], ''The New York Times'', 30 May 2009.</ref> |reported deaths= [[Death of Ian Tomlinson|Ian Tomlinson]], a newspaper vendor |reported property damage= |suspects= |charges= Delroy "Tony" Smellie, a [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan police officer]], charged with assaulting Nicola Fisher<ref>Lewis, Paul. [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/16/delroy-smellie-pleads-not-guilty Riot officer denies hitting G20 activist], ''The Guardian'', 16 November 2010.</ref> He was later found to have committed no crime and found not guilty at court.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8597217.stm | work=BBC News | title=Policeman cleared of G20 assault | date=31 March 2010| accessdate= 25 June 2011 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> |convictions= Phillip Georgopoulos, a student from [[Dudley]] who threw a computer monitor through the window of an RBS branch, was jailed for two-and-a-half years<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8513204.stm|title=Bank vandalism student jailed for G20 demo violence|work=BBC News|date=12 February 2010|accessdate=15 February 2010}}</ref> |publication bans= |lawsuits= |awards= |url= |notes= }} The '''2009 G20 London summit protests''' occurred in the days around the 2 April [[2009 G20 London summit]]. The summit was the focus of protests from a number of groups over various long-standing and topical issues. These ranged from disquiet over economic policy, anger at the banking system and bankers' remuneration and bonuses, the continued [[war on terror]] and concerns over [[climate change]].
Although the majority of the protests and protesters were peaceful, the threat of violence and criminal damage were used by police as a reason to detain, or "[[kettling|kettle]]", protesters as part of [[Operation Glencoe]]. A bystander, [[death of Ian Tomlinson|Ian Tomlinson]], died shortly after being pushed to the ground by a police officer. A second [[post-mortem]] revealed that Tomlinson may have died from an [[Bleeding|abdominal haemorrhage]]. The inquest into Tomlinson's death found that he was unlawfully killed.
==Timeline of the protests== {{Wikinews|G20 protests: Inside a labour march}} [[Image:Put People First march WDM G20 monster.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Put People First march; 28 March]]
;28 March 2009: 35,000 people<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/28/g20-protest-police-rainbow-alliance |author1=Tracy McVeigh |author2=Paul Lewis |author3=Alok Jha |title=G20 protest: Thousands march for 'jobs, justice and climate' |publisher=The Guardian |date=28 March 2009 |location=London |accessdate=7 April 2009 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331024124/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/mar/28/g20-protest-police-rainbow-alliance |archivedate=31 March 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> joined the peaceful "March for Jobs, Justice and Climate" in [[central London]], which was organised by ''Put People First'', a [[civil society|civil-society]] coalition of more than 160 development [[non-governmental organisation]]s, [[trade unions]] and environmental groups, organised in response to the London summit .<ref>[http://www.putpeoplefirst.org.uk/ putpeoplefirst.org], Put People First official website. Accessed 2009-06-12. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hjTWcKfj?url=http://www.putpeoplefirst.org.uk/ Archived] 2009-06-22.</ref>
Their 12-point economic plan for democratic governance demanded democratised financial institutions to deliver secure jobs and public services, an end to global poverty and inequality, and a green economy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.putpeoplefirst.org.uk/2009/03/our-12-point-plan-for-democratic-economic-governance |title=Our 12-point plan for democratic economic governance |date=13 March 2009 |work=Put People First |accessdate=2009-04-24 }}. Accessed 2009-06-12. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hjTWcKfj?url=http://www.putpeoplefirst.org.uk/ Archived] 2009-06-22.</ref> The movement was initiated by the [[Jubilee Debt Campaign]], [[Trade Justice Movement]], British Overseas NGOs for Development and [[Trades Union Congress|TUC]]. [[File:G20 crowd 3.jpg|thumb|upright|G20 Meltdown – 1 April 12:30 pm]]
A peace activist climbed over the railings into the [[Palace of Westminster|Houses of Parliament]] as a symbolic gesture of "power to the people". When arrested by police he explained that "This is the people's parliament, and I am one of the people".
;28 March 2009: Marches in several French cities were organised by [[ATTAC|Association for the Taxation of Financial Transactions for the Aid of Citizens]].<ref>[http://www.france.attac.org/spip.php?article9685 ''Nous ne paierons pas pour leur crise ! Venez le dire avec nous, samedi 28 mars''], Attac France. Accessed 2009-06-12. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hjTX4tuD?url=http://www.france.attac.org/spip.php?article9685 Archived] 2009-06-22.</ref><ref>[http://www.stop-g20.org/ Stop-g-20.org], official website of the protests in France. Accessed 2009-06-12. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hjTXSZmm?url=http://www.stop-g20.org/ Archived] 2009-06-22.</ref>
;1 April 2009 12 noon Around five thousand people joined the "[[2009 G20 London summit protests#G20 Meltdown|G20 Meltdown]]" protest outside the [[Bank of England]].<ref>[http://www.g-20meltdown.org/index.html G20 Meltdown], (advocacy website)</ref> G20 Meltdown was a radical [[anti-capitalist]], [[socialist]] organisation conceived in Paris and formed in London in January 2009 prior to the G20 summit.{{citation needed|date=April 2009}} As well as the protest, they organised four nearby [[squatting|squat]]s. Much of the protest, which was "[[kettling|kettled]]", was peaceful although there were violent confrontations. The police used batons and dogs and at least one policeman was injured; some protesters broke into a branch of [[Royal Bank of Scotland]] and a bystander, [[Death of Ian Tomlinson|Ian Tomlinson]], died after being hit with a baton from behind by a police officer near the protest.
;1 April 2009 <nowiki>12:30 pm</nowiki>[[File:Climate Change Camp 2.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Camp for Climate Action|Climate Camp in the City]] – 1 April 4 pm]] About two to three thousand people joined the "[[Camp for Climate Action|Climate Camp in the City]]" outside [[European Climate Exchange]] on [[Bishopsgate]], which was peaceful except for when minor scuffles occurred after riot police "kettled" the event at 7:30 pm. The street was cleared at about 2 am the following day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/2009/04/426221.html|title=Climate Camp in the city| accessdate= 8 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
;1 April 2009 2 pm Several hundred people joined a peaceful [[Stop the War Coalition]] march from the [[American Embassy, London|American embassy]] in [[Grosvenor Square]] to [[Trafalgar Square]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7975597.stm|title=France demands tougher G20 rules|work=BBC News|accessdate=11 April 2009 | date=1 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090407073144/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7975597.stm| archivedate= 7 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> which brought together protesters from the Stop the War Coalition, [[Palestine Solidarity Campaign]], The British Muslim Initiative, and the [[Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.politics.co.uk/news/policing-and-crime/london-g20-stop-the-war-$1284677.htm |title=London G20: Stop the War |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hjTXsMaR?url=http://www.politics.co.uk/news/policing-and-crime/london-g20-stop-the-war-$1284677.htm |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=2009-06-12 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
;1 April 2009 4 pm An "alternative G20 Summit"<ref>http://www.altg20.org.uk/</ref> with speakers including [[Tony Benn]], [[Ken Loach]], [[Ken Livingstone]], [[John McDonnell (politician)|John McDonnell]] and [[Caroline Lucas]] was scheduled to take place at the [[University of East London]] which was close to the main G20 Summit venue.<ref name="The Alternative G-20">{{cite web|url=http://www.altg20.org.uk/ |title=The Alternative G-20 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hjV67D6O?url=http://www.altg20.org.uk/ |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-12 |df=dmy }}</ref> At the last minute the university announced that the whole university would close for the duration of the summit on safety grounds, also that Prof [[Chris Knight (anthropologist)|Chris Knight]], an anthropologist at the University for 20 years, had been suspended and the alternative summit was cancelled.<ref name="Alternative G20 summit cancelled">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2009/mar/31/g20-university-shuts|title=Alternative G20 summit cancelled|work=The Guardian | location=London | first=Anthea | last=Lipsett | date=31 March 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> In the event, the summit did go ahead and was held on the lawns of the university and started an hour later than planned and an attendance of 200–300 people.<ref name="G20: The revolution will be taught">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/apr/01/g20-alternative-summit-east-london-university|title=G20: The revolution will be taught | work=The Guardian | location=London | date=1 April 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29 | first=Richard | last=Rogers}}</ref>
;2 April 2009: Around 200 people gathered for a vigil outside Bank following news of Ian Tomlinson's death, and were subjected to a police "kettle" despite the vigil being peaceful.{{citation needed|date=April 2009}} 200 anti-war protesters from the [[Stop the War Coalition]] protested at the [[ExCeL Centre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stratfordandnewhamexpress.co.uk/content/newham/express/news/story.aspx?brand=SNEOnline&category=news&tBrand=northlondon24&tCategory=newssne&itemid=WeED02%20Apr%202009%2012%3A08%3A19%3A447 |title=Demonstrators at ExCeL centre for G20 summit |author=Stratford &amp Newham Express |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hjTuMSdD?url=http://www.stratfordandnewhamexpress.co.uk/content/newham/express/news/story.aspx?brand=SNEOnline&category=news&tBrand=northlondon24&tCategory=newssne&itemid=WeED02%20Apr%202009%2012%3A08%3A19%3A447 |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-12 |df= }}</ref>
;2 April 2009: "Spiderman", the French climber [[Alain Robert]], climbed the [[Lloyd's building]] and unfurled a banner saying "100 months to save the world" in reference to the urgency of tackling climate change.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/g20-summit/5095067/G20-summit-Spiderman-Alain-Robert-climbs-Lloyds-building.html|title=G20 summit: 'Spiderman' Alain Robert climbs Lloyd's building | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | date=2 April 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100411084442/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/g20-summit/5095067/G20-summit-Spiderman-Alain-Robert-climbs-Lloyds-building.html| archivedate= 11 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Put People First==
On 28 March 2009, 35,000 people marched through London. At a rally in [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]], they were addressed by [[Global Call to Action Against Poverty]] co-chair [[Kumi Naidoo]], [[Trades Union Congress|TUC]] General Secretary [[Brendan Barber]], environmentalist [[Tony Juniper]], activist comedian [[Mark Thomas]], and global justice author Susan George amongst others. They heard calls for international action to deliver tax justice, [[trade justice]] and a [[Green New Deal]] in both rich and poor countries.<ref>http://www.putpeoplefirst.org.uk/2009/03/35000-thanks-a-strong-signal-to-the-g20-from-the-london-put-people-first-march/. Accessed 2009-06-12. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hjTWcKfj?url=http://www.putpeoplefirst.org.uk/ Archived] 2009-06-22.</ref>
The Put People First alliance of more than 160 unions, development, faith and environment groups called on the G20 leaders to recognise that "only just, fair and sustainable policies can lead the world out of recession, and that a return to 'business as usual' – with the associated poverty, inequality and climate change – is not an option".
Christian NGOs including World Vision and Tearfund organised an ecumenical service on the day at Methodist Central Hall, overseen by the Bishop of London. Delegations joined the march from around the world, including Belgium, Czech Republic, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Luxemburg, Netherlands, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Spain, Korea, USA, Australia, South Africa, Zambia, Canada and the Philippines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bond.org.uk/pages/economic-crisis-campaign.html|title=404 Not Found|publisher=|access-date=22 April 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416101446/http://www.bond.org.uk/pages/economic-crisis-campaign.html|archive-date=16 April 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==G20 Meltdown==
[[Image:G20 meltdown march routes.png|right|upright|thumb|Routes of the marches]]
This protest took place outside the Bank of England. The aim was to "create a carnival outside the bank" and to "overthrow capitalism".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.g-20meltdown.org/node/31 |title=who are we |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hjV46MCH?url=http://www.g-20meltdown.org/node/31 |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-12 |df=dmy }}</ref> Protesters referred to the day as "Financial Fools' Day", a reference to the protest taking place on [[April Fools' Day]].<ref name=reutersapril2/> [[Image:G20 crowd 2.jpg|left|thumb|Protesters with one of the 'Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse']]
The protest started at 11:25<ref name=BBCBuildup>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7973178.stm|title=Live: G20 Summit Build-up|work=BBC News|accessdate=2009-04-15 | date=1 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090405131825/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7973178.stm| archivedate= 5 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> as four planned marches, each led by one of the "[[Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse]]", converged on the Bank: the red horse against war approached from [[Moorgate]]; the green horse against climate chaos from [[Liverpool Street station]]; the silver horse against financial crimes from [[London Bridge]] and the black horse against land enclosures and borders from [[Cannon Street]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.g-20meltdown.org/node/27 |title=Whats happening |publisher=G-20 Meltdown |accessdate=7 April 2009 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090406153039/http://www.g-20meltdown.org/node/27 |archivedate=6 April 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> Protesters were at the Bank of England by 11:53.{{citation needed|date=April 2009}} Protest chants included "build a bonfire, put the bankers on the top", and some protesters shouted "jump" and "shame on you" at bankers watching from windows.<ref name=reutersapril2>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/UKNews1/idUKTRE53101020090402|title=G20 protesters smash windows and clash with police|last=Maclean|first=William|author2=Kate Holton|date=2 April 2009|work=Reuters|accessdate=2009-04-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090406003651/http://uk.reuters.com/article/UKNews1/idUKTRE53101020090402| archivedate= 6 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The police cordoned off thousands of protesters at 12:52<ref name=BBCBuildup/> and many of those within the cordon were not allowed to leave for up to seven hours.<ref name="guardian" /> [[Tom Brake]], a Member of Parliament and legal observer who was among those "kettled", has criticised this tactic.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.suttonguardian.co.uk/news/4269504.MP_Tom_Brake_held_with_G20_protesters/|title=Carshalton and Wallington MP Tom Brake held with G20 protesters for five hours|last=Portilho-Shrimpton|first=Thais|date=6 April 2009|work=Sutton Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-24}}</ref>
[[Image:G20 banners.jpg|right|thumb|A protester hanging banners from the Bank of England]]
Protesters from the group [[Space Hijackers]] were arrested for impersonating police, after being stopped while in a blue 10-ton armoured vehicle, wearing blue boiler suits and riot helmets.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/article2355981.ece|title=Cops confiscate rioter's tank|last=Larcombe|first=Duncan|date=2 April 2009|work=The Sun|accessdate=2009-04-24|location=London}}</ref>
The windows of a branch of the [[Royal Bank of Scotland]] were broken by a group of protesters at 13:45,<ref name=BBCBuildup/> some of whom entered the building and looted office equipment and papers and threw smoke grenades, chairs and eggs<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/g20-summit/5089240/G20-protests-Rioters-loot-RBS-office-after-clashes-in-City.html|title=G20 protests: Rioters loot RBS office after clashes in City|work=The Telegraph|date=1 April 2009|accessdate=2009-04-09 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090404021728/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/g20-summit/5089240/G20-protests-Rioters-loot-RBS-office-after-clashes-in-City.html| archivedate= 4 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> There was intense media attention to this event, with a ring of photographers surrounding the people breaking the windows<ref name="clash1">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7977489.stm|title=Police clash with G20 protesters|date=1 April 2009|publisher=bbc.co.uk|accessdate=2 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090403022410/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7977489.stm| archivedate= 3 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and [[David Howarth]] MP later commented that one of the unresolved mysteries of the day was why the moment that a masked person threw the first piece of scaffolding through the window it was observed by hundreds of photographers and film crews already in position.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.inthenews.co.uk/infocus/features/in-focus/g20-protests-the-politician-s-view-$1286698.htm |title=G20 protests: The politician's view |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hjV4Rkzs?url=http://www.inthenews.co.uk/infocus/features/in-focus/g20-protests-the-politician-s-view-$1286698.htm |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-12 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Four people, including a 17-year-old girl, have been charged in connection to this damage.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/g20-summit/5096877/G20-protests-Four-charged-over-RBS-attack.html|title=G20 protests: Four charged over RBS attack |last=Edwards|first=Richard|author2=Nick Allen, Caroline Gammell and John Bingham|date=9 April 2009|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=2009-04-09 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090406040945/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/g20-summit/5096877/G20-protests-Four-charged-over-RBS-attack.html| archivedate= 6 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> RBS has asked for £40,000 in damages from the teenage girl, who has admitted burglary and criminal damage.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8016350.stm|title=Bank wants £40,000 from G20 girl|date=24 April 2009|work=BBC News|accessdate=2009-04-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090427083134/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8016350.stm| archivedate= 27 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Following the damage to the bank there were violent confrontations with the police with police using batons against the protesters while trying to push them back.<ref name="clash1" /> Some protesters fought back, including one masked protester who hit police with a pole, resulting in one injury and a smoke or flour bomb was also thrown.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-cXqYN7IqQc |title=Policemen Hurt As Protest G20 Heats Up |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hjV4s1um?url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-cXqYN7IqQc&feature=related&feature=related |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-12 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A branch of [[HSBC]] also had windows smashed.<ref name="clash1" /> A journalist reported that the police "were spat on, hit and had vile abuse screamed into their faces from inches away."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/G20/article6021114.ece|title=G20 protests: how the police lost control|last=Fresco|first=Adam|date=2 April 2009|work=The Times|accessdate=2009-04-24 | location=London}}</ref>
A professional photographer saw what they described as "[[Agent provocateur|agents provocateurs]]" instigating violence. One who was throwing bottles was challenged by protesters, who accused him of being a police officer. He ran to police lines and was allowed through after showing I.D.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/04/02/protesters-fail-to-bring-down-global-capitalism-with-costumes-puppets/|title=Did Costumes and Props Undercut the Seriousness of the G-20 Protests?|last=Mackey|first=Robert|date=5 April 2009|work=The Lede (The New York Times News Blog)|accessdate=2009-04-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090406074608/http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/04/02/protesters-fail-to-bring-down-global-capitalism-with-costumes-puppets/| archivedate= 6 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><!---Note: this is from the official NYT news blog, a reliable source---> Tom Brake MP has also said that members of the crowd told him about suspected agents provocateurs who had been encouraging the crowd to throw objects at the police. A police spokesman said that "We would never deploy officers in this way or condone such behaviour."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/may/10/g20-policing-agent-provacateurs|title=G20 police 'used undercover men to incite crowds'|last=Doward|first=Jamie|author2=Mark Townsend|date=10 May 2009|work=The Observer|accessdate=2009-05-10 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090512101217/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2009/may/10/g20-policing-agent-provacateurs| archivedate= 12 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[Image:G20 V mask.jpg|thumb|left|A protester dressed as V from ''[[V for Vendetta (film)|V for Vendetta]]'']] Without alternative facilities, people used the entrances to [[Bank–Monument station|Bank Underground station]] as a urinal,<ref name="guardian" /> although the police said that [[Portable toilet|temporary toilets]] and water were made available to protesters.<ref name="clash1" /> As people were eventually allowed to leave at about 20:00, they were asked for their names and addresses, and required to have a photograph taken. They are, under the law, obliged to provide their name and address,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1984/60/section/24 |title=Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 |publisher=Legislation.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> however they did not need to provide the photograph, but those who refused were put back in the pen.<ref name="guardian">{{cite news |author=Duncan Campbell |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/apr/02/g20-protests-police-kettling |title=G20: Did police containment cause more trouble than it prevented? |work=The Guardian |location=London | date=2 April 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
Commander [[Bob Broadhurst]], the officer in charge of policing the G20 protests, said that the "overall mood" of the 1 April demonstrations was good although "unfortunately small groups of protesters intent on violence mixed with the crowds of lawful demonstrators."<ref name=IndSquat/> A bystander, Ian Tomlinson, died after being pushed to the ground by a police officer.<ref name=LewisvideoApril7>Lewis, Paul. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/apr/07/ian-tomlinson-g20-death-video Ian Tomlinson death: Guardian video reveals police attack on man who died at G20 protest], ''The Guardian'', 7 April 2009.</ref>
===Squats=== Protesters set up four [[squatting|squat]]s as bases close to the Bank of England on 31 March.<ref name=guardiansquats>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/31/g20-summit-protests|title=G20 protesters set up camp on City fringes|last=Lewis|first=Paul|author2=Peter Walker and Sandra Laville|date=31 March 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-09 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090403051701/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/mar/31/g20-summit-protests| archivedate= 3 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The police raided an occupied derelict pub in [[Shoreditch]] on the evening of the 31st which had been publicised as a "convergence space for protesters"; they [[Stop and search|stopped and searched]] people entering the building and arrested three people, one on suspicion of assaulting a police officer.<ref name=guardiansquats/>
On 1 April Payne House on Earl Street near Liverpool Street Station was promoted as venue for workshops, films and accommodation with space to house "many, many people". The venue was advertised as a drug-free and alcohol-free centre with no photography allowed without permission.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://london.indymedia.org.uk/articles/930|title=New G20 convergence space opened|accessdate=19 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521014851/https://london.indymedia.org.uk/articles/930|archive-date=21 May 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Police later raided a large Victorian office building in Earl Street and another squatted building, the [[RampART Social Center]], in [[Whitechapel]] on 2 April, detaining a total of at least 80 people and arresting four.<ref name=IndSquat>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/police-braced-for-more-g20-violence-1660167.html|title=Dozens held (including Spiderman) after G20 protest raids | work=The Independent | location=London | date=2 April 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> A video of the raid allegedly shows an officer pointing a [[Taser]] at protesters who are lying on the floor, which would be against police guidelines.<ref name=taser>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article6128584.ece|title=G20 officer ‘pointed Taser at protesters’|last=Fresco|first=Adam|author2=Tom Whipple and Sean O’Neill |date=20 April 2009|work=The Times|accessdate=2009-04-24 | location=London}}</ref>
==Climate Camp== {{see also|Camp for Climate Action}} <!---Copied from [[Camp for Climate Action]], version [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Camp_for_Climate_Action&oldid=284835639] under GFDL---> [[File:Climate camp in the city - happy people.JPG|thumb|left|Protesters at the climate camp]] The "Camp in the City" ({{coord|51.5152|-0.0825|type:landmark}}) on 1 April 2009 aimed to draw attention to [[carbon emission trading|carbon trading]], claiming that far from being a way of reducing release of climate change gasses in the atmosphere it is used as an excuse to continue doing just that.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.climatecamp.org.uk/carbon-trading |title=Carbon trading |publisher=Climate Camp |accessdate=2009-04-07 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hjV5IF5W?url=http://www.climatecamp.org.uk/carbon-trading |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> The camp took place outside the [[European Climate Exchange]] in [[Bishopsgate]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/G20-Summit-Protests-Guide-To-Whats-Going-To-Happen-And-When/Article/200904115253140?videoSourceID=2fa12d8859160210VgnVCM1000005d04170aRCRD&lpos=UK_News_Article_Inline_Player_List_0&lid=ARTICLE_15253140_G20_Summit_Protests%3A_Guide_To_Whats_Going_To_Happen_And_When|title=Timetable of Disruption: The Summit Protests|work=Sky News|accessdate=2009-04-07}}</ref>
Prior to the actual camp a group of participants had played a game called "capture the flag" in the area on 27 March which was used by the protesters to familiarise themselves with the locale.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/uk/7961868.stm|title=Eco-activists prepare for protest|work=BBC News | accessdate= 19 April 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
Climate Camp organisers agreed to meet with police and exchange contact details shortly before the protest. The meeting was arranged by [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] MP [[David Howarth]], who was to mediate at the meeting which was to take place at the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]]. Scotland Yard confirmed that a meeting was to take place with police Commander Bob Broadhurst and Chief Superintendent Ian Thomas.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/30/g20-police-agree-talks-protesters|title=Police agree to urgent talks with G20 protesters | work=The Guardian | location=London | first=Paul | last=Lewis | date=30 March 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
The camp, which was intended to last for 24 hours, started at 12:30 pm when a camp was established in a section of Bishopsgate between [[Threadneedle Street]] and [[London Wall]] with tents set up and bunting across the road reading "Nature doesn't do bailouts".<ref name=BBC_eyewitness>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7977863.stm|title=Eyewitness: Climate Camp in the City|accessdate=2009-04-07|work=BBC news | date=1 April 2009|first=Dominic|last=Casciani| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090404115604/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7977863.stm| archivedate= 4 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> There were solar-powered sound systems, musicians and a food stall and some 1,000-plus relaxed people.<ref name=skypeace>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.news.sky.com/thedailyplanet/Post:82f1acc3-041a-48d7-a5aa-b8efc8c96522 |title=Peace, love and riot police |work=Sky news |accessdate=2009-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016065241/http://blogs.news.sky.com/thedailyplanet/Post%3A82f1acc3-041a-48d7-a5aa-b8efc8c96522 |archivedate=16 October 2009 |df= }}</ref> [[Image:G20 climate camp police kettling protesters.jpg|thumb|right|Riot police 'kettle' protesters]] The atmosphere was still relaxed at about 5 pm when police with helmets, shields and batons began to surround areas of the camp using section 14 of the [[Public Order Act 1986]].<ref name=skypeace/>
At about 7 pm the police stopped allowing people to enter or leave the protest.<ref name=beth>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/libertycentral/2009/apr/02/g20-protest-climate-camp |title=G20: The police ruined a peaceful protest |work=Guardian |accessdate=2009-04-07 |location=London |date=2 April 2009 |first=Beth |last=McGrath |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090405145827/http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/libertycentral/2009/apr/02/g20-protest-climate-camp |archivedate=5 April 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The police advanced on protesters who put their hands in the air and passively resisted while chanting "This is not a riot",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planestupid.com/content/police-brutality-camp-climate-action-city-london|title=Police brutality at Camp for Climate Action in the City of London|publisher=[[Plane Stupid]]|accessdate=2009-04-07}}</ref> a tactic that emerged over the course of a number of Camp for Climate Action gatherings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://young.anabaptistradicals.org/2009/04/03/this-is-not-a-riot-an-effective-nonviolent-response-to-attacks-by-riot-police/|title=This is not a riot: an effective, nonviolent response to attacks by riot police|publisher=Young Anabaptist Radicals|accessdate=2009-04-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090407042458/http://young.anabaptistradicals.org/2009/04/03/this-is-not-a-riot-an-effective-nonviolent-response-to-attacks-by-riot-police/| archivedate= 7 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> There were scuffles with the police in which several protesters were hit and kicked by the police and one policewoman needed medical attention.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2009/apr/02/g20-climate-camp-protest-london-police-bishopsgate|title=G20 Climate Camp anger simmers in the kettle|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-07 | location=London | date=2 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090405015626/http://www.guardian.co.uk/environment/blog/2009/apr/02/g20-climate-camp-protest-london-police-bishopsgate| archivedate= 5 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Within the cordon people carried on playing music and preparing food and until the police began letting people leave at about 11:30 pm<ref name=beth/> and cleared the area of the last protesters at about 2 am.<ref name=skypeace/>
Organizers of the Climate Camp have released a report of the protests and the police response, "Demonstrating Respect for Rights", which includes allegations of police using violence to clear the camp after journalists had left.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8008980.stm|title=G20 probe 'must be independent'|work=BBC News|accessdate=2009-04-24 | date=20 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090423071711/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8008980.stm| archivedate= 23 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The camp legal team also released a video of the protests, which includes footage of a demonstrator being struck on the head by a police riot shield, and of another man being punched in the face as the crowd retreats from police.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article6122785.ece|title=Police beat another G20 protester|last=Gourlay|first=Chris|date=19 April 2009|work=Sunday Times|accessdate=2009-04-24 | location=London}}</ref>
==Alternative London Summit== [[Image:Alternative London Summit Mark Thomas 2009.jpeg|thumb|upright|Mark Thomas – 1 April]]
An "alternative G20 Summit" with speakers including [[Tony Benn]], [[Ken Loach]], [[Ken Livingstone]], [[John McDonnell (politician)|John McDonnell]] and [[Caroline Lucas]] was scheduled to take place at the [[University of East London]], which is close to where the main G20 Summit was held.<ref name="The Alternative G-20" /> At the last minute the university announced that the whole university would close for the duration of the summit on safety grounds, also that Prof [[Chris Knight (anthropologist)|Chris Knight]], an expert in anthropology at the University for 20 years, had been suspended for "inciting criminal action, specifically violence against policemen and women and damage to banking institutions", and that the alternative summit was cancelled.<ref name="Alternative G20 summit cancelled" /> In the event, the summit did go ahead and was held on the lawns of the university and started an hour later than planned; 200–300 people attended.<ref name="G20: The revolution will be taught"/><ref>[http://www.chrisknight.co.uk/altg20/ Original Alternative G20 summit website]</ref>
==Policing==
[[Image:G20 police lines.jpg|left|thumb|Police lines at the G20 Meltdown protest]]
===Operation Glencoe=== [[Image:Riot Police.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Riot police at the protest]] Scotland Yard officers drew up Operation Glencoe, the plan to protect the summit and prevent disorder. The overall commander (the [[Gold Silver Bronze command structure|Gold commander]]) was Commander Bob Broadhurst.<ref>[http://cms.met.police.uk/news/updates/operation_glencoe_policing_and_security_for_the_g20_london_summit Operation Glencoe policing and security for the G20 London Summit], Metropolitan Police Service, 2 April 2009; accessed 18 April 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hjV3fxk0?url=http://cms.met.police.uk/news/updates/operation_glencoe_policing_and_security_for_the_g20_london_summit Archived] 2009-06-22.</ref>
Before the event Commander Simon O'Brien said that the capital would see "almost unprecedented level of activity" of protest activity with seven officially notified demonstrations and possibly many more they don't know about. [[Scotland Yard]] described the G20 policing plan as one of the largest, most challenging and complicated public order operations it has ever devised. They said that the level and style of activity on the internet suggested a re-emergence of groups with similar aims to the anti-globalisation protesters who turned to violence in 2000 and 2001. They said they were determined to avoid the violent scenes of the 2001 [[27th G8 summit|G8 in Genoa]] in which one protester was killed and hundreds more injured.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7971212.stm|title=The challenge of policing the G20|work=BBC news | date=30 March 2009 | accessdate=2010-01-01}}</ref> In the days leading up to the summit, the [[Metropolitan police]] warned protest groups that the protests on 1 April would be "very violent" and that they were "up for it, and up to it" in the event of trouble.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/mar/27/g20-protest|title=Fears police tactics at G20 protests will lead to violence|last=Lewis|first=Paul|author2=Sandra Laville, John Vidal|date=27 March 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-08 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090330060646/http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2009/mar/27/g20-protest| archivedate= 30 March 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[Image:G20 injured protester and police.jpg|right|thumb|An injured protester with police medics]] The police used the crowd-control tactic known as containment or the “[[Kettling|kettle]]”, to hold 5,000 people inside a police cordon without food, drink or lavatory facilities.<ref>Similar tactics had been used in New York [https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/02/politics/campaign/02protest.html?_r=1 Tactics by Police Mute the Protesters, and Their Messages] New York Times</ref> This combined with riot police pushing into crowds with shields and batons. <ref name="timesonline.co.uk">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article6073436.ece|title=Metropolitan police chiefs ordered to justify tactics at G20 protests|work=The Times | location=London | first=Sean | last=O'Neill | date=11 April 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
Ian Tomlinson died after being shoved and struck by a police officer within a police cordon of the G20 Meltdown protest near the Bank of England. Initially the City of London Police denied that any incident with the police had occurred, and the death was attributed to natural causes.
Including a number of raids on squats on 2 April 2009, the police made over 100 arrests and said they had identified and would track down those who had broken the law. A teenage girl was convicted of criminal damage<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/apr/03/g20-teenage-girl-jail | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Teenage girl faces jail over G20 violence | first=Anil | last=Dawar | date=3 April 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> An estimated 5,000 people took part in the protests.<ref name="deal1">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7978105.stm |title=G20 leaders seal $1tn global deal |date=2 April 2009 |publisher=bbc.co.uk |accessdate=2 April 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090402012950/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7978105.stm| archivedate= 2 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> It has been suggested that the policing of the event will turn out to have been the most expensive police operation in British history at an estimated cost of up to £8 million, or £1,600 per protester.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/g20-summit/5023042/G20-to-be-most-expensive-police-operation-in-British-history.html|title=G20 to be most expensive police operation in British history|work=The Telegraph | location=London | first=Richard | last=Edwards | date=20 March 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
One raid on a climate change group the day after the main protests was ruled to have been illegal in March 2010, the Met Commissioner said that it was unlawful to arrest and search protestors and to force them to be recorded on film. Two protesters were each awarded £3000 compensation after the Met admitted the operation was unlawful as there were no reasonable grounds for suspicion.<ref>[http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/uk/met+police+to+pay+g20+protest+compensation/3587057 Met police to pay G20 protest compensation] Channel 4 News 22 March 2010</ref>
===Response to police tactics=== The police choice of "Operation Glencoe" as a codename was linked with the [[Glencoe Massacre]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/28/g20-protests-london | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=G20 protests: Cry havoc – and let slip a rainbow alliance of summit protesters | first=Paul | last=Lewis | date=28 March 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7973178.stm | work=BBC News | title=Live: G20 Summit Build-up | date=1 April 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> In the buildup to the protests the chairman of the [[Joint Committee on Human Rights]], [[Andrew Dismore|Andrew Dismore, MP]], said that "The police have a duty under the Human Rights Act to facilitate protest and not frustrate it. If they act in a confrontational way and use confrontation language, they will start to provoke the kind of behaviour they are seeking to prevent. There may well be a fringe element that want to incite violence. But that doesn't mean police should criminalise every protester." [[David Howarth]], a Liberal Democrat MP, said: "I am increasingly worried that what the police are saying about the protests will end up in a self-fulfilling prophecy. By talking up the prospect of violence they [the police] will put off peaceful demonstrators and start to attract other sorts."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/mar/27/g20-protest | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Fears police tactics at G20 protests will lead to violence | first=Paul | last=Lewis | date=27 March 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
[[Jenny Jones (Green politician)|Jenny Jones]], a member of the [[Metropolitan Police Authority]], said of reports of [[police brutality]] that "If the police were hitting people who were sitting down with their hands up, we have entered a new era of overt violent policing in Britain that will deter people from protesting and cut back our civil liberties". A police Commander said that their "tactics were proportionate and worked".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7981932.stm|title=Concern over G20 police tactics |date=3 April 2009|work=BBC News|accessdate=2009-04-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090406074158/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7981932.stm| archivedate= 6 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Jean Lambert|Jean Lambert, MEP]], of the London [[Green Party of England and Wales|Green Party]], wrote an open letter to the Metropolitan Police Commissioner after the event asking for an explanation of the police tactics at the climate camp.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenparty.org.uk/region/london/news/2009-04-03formal-letter-to-metropolitan-police-commissioner-sir-paul-stephenson.html |title=Formal letter to Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Paul Stephenson |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hjV5hbom?url=http://www.greenparty.org.uk/region/london/news/2009-04-03formal-letter-to-metropolitan-police-commissioner-sir-paul-stephenson.html |archivedate=22 June 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-12 |df=dmy }}</ref>
A number of allegations of police misconduct have been reported, including by a press photographer.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/apr/11/g20-protest-witnesses-police-actions|title=The G20 protesters' stories: Allegations over police treatment on the frontline|last=Lewis|first=Paul|author2=Peter Walker|date=11 April 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-14 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090414054940/http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2009/apr/11/g20-protest-witnesses-police-actions| archivedate= 14 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The IPCC has received 185 complaints relating to police actions at the demonstrations, 40 of which were ineligible<ref name=proud>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8009939.stm |title=Minister is 'proud' of G20 police |date=21 April 2009 |work=BBC News |accessdate=2009-04-24 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090424081731/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8009939.stm |archivedate=24 April 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> and 80 of which concern violence.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/apr/11/g20-ian-tomlinson-death|title=G20 police officers may face multiple claims over brutality allegations|last=Lewis|first=Paul|author2=Afua Hirsch|date=11 April 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-14 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090413142210/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2009/apr/11/g20-ian-tomlinson-death| archivedate= 13 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=eager/> An officer is being investigated and has received a written warning after writing "Rob Ward can't wait to bash some long haired hippys up @ the G20" as a [[Facebook]] status update on the evening of 1 April. Liberal Democrat MP [[Chris Huhne]] has noted "the canteen culture of some parts of the Met".<ref name=eager>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8016620.stm|title=Pc 'eager to hit G20 protesters'|date=24 April 2009|work=BBC News|accessdate=2009-04-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090426234314/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8016620.stm| archivedate= 26 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The [[National Union of Journalists]] has considered taking legal action after Section 14 of the [[Public Order Act 1986]] was used against journalists covering the protests on 2 April. The City of London police asked them to leave the area at the Royal Exchange for half an hour, and threatened arrest if they refused.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/apr/17/g20-police-photographers-nuj|title=G20: NUJ considers legal action over police treatment of photographers|last=Brook|first=Stephen|date=17 April 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-24 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090420034123/http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2009/apr/17/g20-police-photographers-nuj| archivedate= 20 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Section 14 is to prevent "serious public disorder, serious criminal damage or serious disruption to the life of the community". The police earlier apologised to journalists reporting the 1 April protests at the Bank of England: "Section 14 was applied outside the Bank of England to disperse protesters. There may have been some photographers caught up in that. If so we apologise. We respect the right of photographers to cover current events."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/apr/08/g20-protest-police-apology-photographers|title=Police apologise for obstructing photographers at G20 protest|last=Sweney|first=Matt|date=8 April 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-24 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090411024435/http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2009/apr/08/g20-protest-police-apology-photographers| archivedate= 11 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[Paul Stephenson (police officer)|Sir Paul Stephenson]], the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, expressed "concern that the video footage of some police actions are clearly disturbing and should be thoroughly investigated", and a need to be reassured that the use of the containment, or [[kettling]] tactic "remains appropriate and proportionate".<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/8000246.stm | work=BBC News | title=Police begin G20 tactics review | date=16 April 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> [[Denis O'Connor (police officer)|Denis O'Connor]] has said that some police behaviour "fell short of the police medal promise to "guard my people"."<ref name=thirdpostmortem/> Others have defended the policing of the protests. [[Ken Jones (police officer)|Sir Ken Jones]], the President of the [[Association of Chief Police Officers]], has criticised the lack of objectivity which he perceives has been shown by the media.<ref>[http://www.acpo.police.uk/pressrelease.asp?PR_GUID={6435E06C-AAAA-49F4-BBA0-A0C7DC4C837A} ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091002191211/http://www.acpo.police.uk/pressrelease.asp?PR_GUID=%7B6435E06C-AAAA-49F4-BBA0-A0C7DC4C837A%7D |date=2 October 2009 }}</ref> Jones went onto question the views put forward by [[Nick Hardwick (chairman)|Nick Hardwick]], the Chair of the IPCC.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/g20-summit/5186142/Policing-of-G20-protests-was-proportionate-Sir-Ken-Jones-says.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=Policing of G20 protests was 'proportionate', Sir Ken Jones says | first=Jon | last=Swaine | date=20 April 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref> Jones also stated that he "can't think of any other country that doesn't use water cannons, CS gas, rubber bullets". The [[Police Federation of England and Wales|Police Federation]] has also criticised the IPCC, making a formal complaint about the "deplorable behaviour" of Nick Hardwick, Chairman of the IPCC, for passing "lofty and withering judgment on London's police officers".<ref name=thirdpostmortem>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/apr/22/ian-tomlinson-g20-protests Ian Tomlinson G20 death: coroner grants request for third postmortem] The Guardian, 22 April 2009</ref> Home Office Minister [[Lord West]] said in the House of Lords that "thousands of officers acted absolutely professionally and proportionately, thousands were actually able to demonstrate peacefully on our streets, criminal activity in the rest of the metropolis was kept to an absolute minimum and the police also maintained high levels of security. And I think we should be extremely proud of them. This does not excuse acts which are criminal and there are now investigations taking place for those particulars."<ref name=proud/> The [[Mayor of London]], [[Boris Johnson]], has defended the police,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/apr/21/boris-johnson-g20-police-met|title=Boris Johnson defends G20 policing|last=Mulholland|first=Hélène|date=21 April 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-24 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090424053522/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/apr/21/boris-johnson-g20-police-met| archivedate= 24 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and said that "I worry that there are large sections of the media that are currently engaged in a very unbalanced orgy of cop bashing".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/apr/23/boris-johnson-g20-police-media|title=Boris Johnson condemns media response to G20 policing|last=Bleaken|first=Nathan|date=23 April 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-04-24 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090426060922/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2009/apr/23/boris-johnson-g20-police-media| archivedate= 26 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Nicola Fisher video=== {{main|Death of Ian Tomlinson#Nicola Fisher video}} On 14 April, media outlets published video taken during a vigil for Ian Tomlinson on 2 April outside the [[Bank of England]], near to where he died. A sergeant with the [[Territorial Support Group]] is seen slapping a woman who was arguing with him, Nicola Fisher, across the face, then striking her legs with his baton. The officer's identification number was concealed.<ref name=Woodwards>Woodwards, Tristan. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V23PGWd46MM G20 April 2, 2009], alleged assault begins at circa 3 minutes, 49 seconds. Accessed 2009-06-12. [https://www.webcitation.org/5hjTukFjE?url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V23PGWd46MM&feature=channel Archived] 2009-06-22.</ref><ref name=LewisApril15>Lewis, Paul. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/apr/15/metropolitan-police-tomlinson-assault-g20 Metropolitan police officer suspended over attack at G20 death vigil], ''The Guardian'', 15 April 2009, accessed 15 April 2009.</ref> The IPCC said it would investigate, and the officer was suspended.<ref name=LewisApril15/> Sir Paul Stephenson said that uniformed officers should always display their shoulder identification numbers, as "The public has a right to be able to identify any uniformed officer whilst performing their duty."<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk" /> In September 2009, the officer was named as Sgt Delroy 'Tony' Smellie, and the [[Crown Prosecution Service|CPS]] announced that it would charge him with assault.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8279001.stm|title=BBC NEWS UK Officer faces G20 assault charge|publisher=news.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=2009-09-28| date=28 September 2009}}</ref> The court case against Delroy Smellie commenced in March 2010 and he has been found not guilty.
Another demonstrator, Katie Surridge, has alleged that she was pushed to the ground from behind on 1 April by the same officer who later struck Nicola Fisher. That incident has also been reported to the IPCC.<ref name=taser/> IPCC have announced that there is no case to answer.
===Review of the policing of public events===
On 15 April 2009, [[Metropolitan Police Commissioner]] [[Sir Paul Stephenson]] asked the [[Chief Inspector of Constabulary]] to review policing tactics in the policing of public events. [[Denis O'Connor (Policeman)|Denis O'Connor]] will review the policing of public events following allegations of two assaults by police during the G20 protests in London on 1 April. He will also assess whether the tactic of containment or [[kettling]] is appropriate and proportionate to ensuring people have the right to protest. He said the event was a "complex policing operation", and that footage of clashes with police will be reviewed to check if other incidents need to be examined. Sir Paul stressed that all uniformed officers must wear shoulder identification numbers to be easily identifiable by the public.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/8000246.stm|title=Police begin G20 tactics review |date=15 April 2005|work=BBC News|accessdate=2009-04-15| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090416195221/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/8000246.stm| archivedate= 16 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Among the tactics being reviewed is the crowd-control tactic known as the “[[Kettling|kettle]]”, used to pen in protesters.<ref name="timesonline.co.uk" /> Bob Broadhurst, the commanding officer during the protests, blamed any misconduct of officers on the lack of training they receive in [[crowd control]] and on fear. He revealed during a Commons Home Affairs Committee that officers only receive 2 days of training a year.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8057685.stm | work=BBC News | title='Training concern' for G20 police | date=19 May 2009 | accessdate=2010-03-29}}</ref>
On Tuesday 25 January 2011, Broadhurst apologised to the home affairs select committee for telling then in May 2009 that no plain-clothes officers were present at the demonstrations; He admitted that numerous City of London police officers had been present at the demonstration, along with more than one Met officer, including PC Mark Kennedy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jan/25/met-undercover-policing-unit-g20|title=Met counter-terrorism chief to take over protest spy unit|author=Rob Evans|work=the Guardian}}</ref>
On 14 April 2011 the high court has ruled that the Metropolitan police broke the law in the way they "kettled" protesters at the G20 demonstrations in 2009, and also criticised the use of force by officers.<ref>{{cite news |first=Vikram |last=Dodd |title=Kettling of G20 protesters by police was illegal, high court rules|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/apr/14/kettling-g20-protesters-police-illegal |work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=|date=14 April 2011 |accessdate=14 April 2011 | location=London}}</ref>
==Death of Ian Tomlinson== {{main|Death of Ian Tomlinson}} {{Wikinews|G20 protester dies after collapsing}} {{Wikinews|Inquiry into death of vendor during G20 protests begins}} Ian Tomlinson, a newspaper vendor in the [[City of London]], died within a police cordon of the G20 Meltdown protest near the Bank of England. Initially the [[City of London Police]] denied that any incident with the police had occurred, and the death was attributed to natural causes. Days later, ''The Guardian'' published video showing Tomlinson had been pushed by a [[Metropolitan Police Service]] officer and hit with a baton minutes before he collapsed and died.<ref name=DoddApril8>Dodd, Vikram. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/apr/08/ian-tomlinson-video-inquiry-ipcc Ian Tomlinson death: IPCC takes over inquiry from G20 protests police force], ''The Guardian'', 8 April 2009.</ref>
The [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]] (IPCC) subsequently ordered a second post mortem and set up an independent criminal inquiry to determine whether Tomlinson was assaulted by police, and whether that assault contributed to his death.<ref name=DoddApril8/> The results of this second post mortem have revealed that Tomlinson actually died from an abdominal haemorrhage. A police officer was questioned under caution about Tomlinson's death.<ref>[http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/world/5506397/uk-cop-questioned-g20-protest-death/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419223500/http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/world/5506397/uk-cop-questioned-g20-protest-death/ |date=19 April 2009 }}</ref>

[[File:Cartesian-coordinate-system.svg|thumb|right|250px|Illustration of a Cartesian coordinate plane, showing the absolute values (unsigned dotted line lengths) of the coordinates of the points (2, 3), (0, 0), (–3, 1), and (–1.5, –2.5). The first value in each of these signed ordered pairs is the abscissa of the corresponding point, and the second value is its ordinate.]] In [[mathematics]], the '''abscissa''' ({{IPAc-en|æ|b|ˈ|s|ɪ|s|.|ə}}; plural ''abscissae'' or ''abscissæ'' or ''abscissas'') and the '''ordinate''' are respectively the first and second [[coordinate]] of a [[Point (geometry)|point]] in a [[coordinate system]].
The '''abscissa''' of a point is the signed [[Measurement|measure]] of its projection on the primary axis, whose absolute value is the distance between the projection and the origin of the axis, and whose sign is given by the location on the projection relative to the origin (before: negative; after: positive).
The '''ordinate''' of a point is the signed [[Measurement|measure]] of its projection on the secondary axis, whose absolute value is the distance between the projection and the origin of the axis, and whose sign is given by the location on the projection relative to the origin (before: negative; after: positive).
Usually these are the horizontal and vertical coordinates of a point in a two-dimensional rectangular [[Cartesian coordinate system]]. The terms can also refer to the horizontal and vertical axes respectively (typically ''x''-axis and ''y''–axis) of a two-dimensional graph. An [[ordered pair]] consists of two terms—the abscissa (horizontal, usually ''x'') and the ordinate (vertical, usually ''y'')—which define the location of a point in two-dimensional rectangular space.
:<math>(\overbrace{x}^\text{abscissa}, \overbrace{y}^\text{ordinate})</math>
== Etymology ==
Though the word "abscissa" (Latin; "linea abscissa", "a line cut off") has been used at least since ''De Practica Geometrie'' published in 1220 by [[Fibonacci]] (Leonardo of Pisa), its use in its modern sense may be due to Venetian mathematician [[Stefano degli Angeli]] in his work ''Miscellaneum Hyperbolicum, et Parabolicum'' of 1659.<ref>{{cite web |title =On the Word "Abscissa" |website =numberwarrior.wordpress.com |last=Dyer |first=Jason |publisher = The number Warrior |date = March 8, 2009 |url = https://numberwarrior.wordpress.com/2009/03/08/on-the-word-abscissa/ |accessdate = September 10, 2015 }}</ref>
In his 1892 work ''Vorlesungen über Geschichte der Mathematik, Volume 2,'' ("''Lectures on history of mathematics''") German historian of mathematics [[Moritz Cantor]] writes
:"Wir kennen keine ältere Benutzung des Wortes Abssisse in lateinischen Originalschriften [than degli Angeli's]. Vielleicht kommt das Wort in Übersetzungen der [[Apollonius_of_Perga|Apollonischen Kegelschnitte]] vor, wo Buch I Satz 20 von ''ἀποτεμνομέναις'' die Rede ist, wofür es kaum ein entsprechenderes lateinisches Wort als ''abscissa'' geben möchte."<ref>{{cite book |title=Vorlesungen über Geschichte der Mathematik, Volume 2 |last=Cantor |first=Moritz |year=1900 |publisher=B.G. Teubner |location= Leipzig |page=898 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LejuAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA898&lpg=PA898&dq=%22Miscellaneum+Hyperbolicum,+et+Parabolicum.%22+%22abscissa%22&source=bl&ots=gUXz-_IZhC&sig=v2-RKHUt3CkqWh2EgxBhIbc9JcY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAmoVChMIrY3q_8rtxwIVQaGACh29JQuB#v=onepage&q=%22Miscellaneum%20Hyperbolicum%2C%20et%20Parabolicum.%22%20%22abscissa%22&f=false |accessdate=10 September 2015}}</ref>
:"We know no earlier use of the word abscissa in Latin originals [than degli Angeli's]. Maybe the word descends from translations of the [[Apollonius_of_Perga|Apollonian conics]], where in Book I, Chapter 20 there appears ''ἀποτεμνομέναις,'' for which there would hardly be as an appropriate Latin word as ''abscissa.''"
==In parametric equations== In a somewhat obsolete variant usage, the abscissa of a point may also refer to any number that describes the point's location along some path, e.g. the parameter of a [[parametric equation]].<ref name="WolframAlpha">{{cite web |last=Hedegaard |first=Rasmus |last2=Weisstein |first2=Eric W. |title=Abscissa |work=[[MathWorld]] |url=http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Abscissa.html |accessdate=14 July 2013}}</ref> Used in this way, the abscissa can be thought of as a coordinate-geometry analog to the [[Independent_variable#Independent_variable|independent variable]] in a [[mathematical model]] or experiment (with any ordinates filling a role analogous to [[Dependent and independent variables#Dependent_variable|dependent variables]]).
==See also== {{Portal|Geometry}}

{{expand Spanish|topic=hist|date=October 2016}} [[File:Codex Totomixtlahuaca WDL2701.png|thumb|Codex Totomixtlahuaca]] The '''Codex Totomixtlahuaca''' or '''Codex Condumex''' is a colonial-era map produced on a large piece of [[cotton]]. The map represents Totomixlahuaca, [[Mexico]], and includes a creation date of 1564. It documents a meeting over a land conflict in communities of the current Mexican state of [[Guerrero]].
== Description == The ''Codex Totomixtlahuaca'' was found in the community of Totomixtlahuaca, located in the southeast of Guerrero, in [[Mexico]]. Using Aztec [[pictogram|pictographs]], the map represents the distribution of lands in 1564.<ref name="wdl" />
== Preparation == The map was drawn on a large piece of cotton, roughly 217 cm by 185 cm. It was painted with coal.<ref name="cehm" />
== References == {{Reflist|2|refs = <ref name="wdl">{{cite web |url= http://www.wdl.org/es/item/2701// |title=Códice Totomixtlahuaca |first= |last=|publisher=Biblioteca Digital Mundial |date=10 December 2015}}</ref> <ref name="cehm">{{cite web |url= http://www.archivo.cehmcarso.com.mx/janium-bin/janium_login_opac.pl?find&ficha_no=137482 |title=Ficha técnica |publisher=Centro de Estudios de Historia de México|date=10 December 2015}}</ref>}}
