{{original research|date=June 2018}} {{globalize/US|date=June 2018}} [[File:Teal ribbon.svg|right|thumb|Sexual assault awareness is represented by the color teal.{{Cite web|url=https://www.supportstore.com/awareness-sexual-assault.html|title=Sexual Assault Awareness|website=SupportStore.com|access-date=2018-04-29}}]] '''[[Sexual assault]] of [[LGBT]] persons''' is a form of violence that occurs within the LGBT community. While sexual assault and other forms of interpersonal violence can occur in all forms of relationships, it is found that sexual minorities experience it at rates that are equal to or higher than their heterosexual counterparts.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/cdc_nisvs_victimization_final-a.pdf|title=NISVS: An Overview of 2010 Findings on Victimization by Sexual Orientation|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} There is a lack of research on this specific problem for the LGBT population as a whole, but there does exist a substantial amount of research on college LGBT students who have experienced sexual assault. == Definition == There are varying definitions as to what sexual assault is defined as. According to the [[United States Department of Justice]]:
"The term 'sexual assault' means any nonconsensual sexual act proscribed by Federal, tribal, or State law, including when the victim lacks capacity to consent."{{Cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/ovw/sexual-assault|title=Sexual Assault {{!}} OVW {{!}} Department of Justice|website=www.justice.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-04-30}}
Definitions and laws of sexual assault vary from state to state. The website [https://statelaws.findlaw.com/criminal-laws/sexual-assault.html FindLaw] allows users to click on their corresponding to state to read about how their state defines what sexual assault is, as well as what laws and limitations exist. Sexual assault of LGBT individuals refers to the act of sexual violence against persons who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender amongst other sexualities and sexual minorities. == Statistics == The [[Rape, Abuse and Incest National Network]], also known as RAINN, puts out general statistics{{Cite web|url=https://www.rainn.org/statistics/victims-sexual-violence|title=Victims of Sexual Violence: Statistics {{!}} RAINN|website=www.rainn.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-30}} of sexual assault, including: * Every 98 seconds, an American is sexually assaulted. * 21% of TGQN (transgender, genderqueer, nonconforming) college students have been sexually assaulted. According to a 2010 findings{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/cdc_nisvs_victimization_final-a.pdf|title=NISVS: An Overview of 2010 Findings on Victimization by Sexual Orientation|last=|first=|date=|website=Centers for Disease Control|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} on [https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/cdc_nisvs_victimization_final-a.pdf The National Intimate Partner and Sexual Violence Survey], put out by the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]], it concluded that: * For Lesbian women: ** 44% experienced rape, physical violence, and/or stalking by an intimate partner in their lifetime. ** Approximately 1 in 8 (13%) have been raped in their lifetime. * For Gay men: ** 26% experienced rape, physical violence, and/or stalking by an intimate partner in their lifetime. ** 4 in 10 (40%) have experienced sexual violence other than rape in their lifetime. * Bisexual Women: ** 61% experienced rap, physical violence, and/or stalking by an intimate partner at some point in their lifetime. ** 1 in 5 (22%) have been raped by an intimate partner in their lifetime. ** 46% have been raped in their lifetime. * Bisexual Men: ** 37% experienced rape, physical violence, and/or stalking by an intimate partner in their lifetime. ** 47% have experienced sexual violence other than rape in their lifetime. In a paper done by Emily Rothman, Deinera Exner, and Allyson Baughman, it was found that, in regard to lifetime sexual assault victimization, the estimated prevalence for lesbian and bisexual women was approximately 12.6 - 85%. For gay and bisexual men, it was 11.8-54.0%.{{Cite journal|last=Rothman|first=Emily F.|last2=Exner|first2=Deinera|last3=Baughman|first3=Allyson | date = April 2011 |title=The prevalence of sexual assault against people who identify as Gay, Lesbian or Bisexual in the United States: A systematic review |journal=Trauma, violence & abuse|volume=12|issue=2|pages=55–66|doi=10.1177/1524838010390707 |pmc=3118668|pmid=21247983}} == Underlying issues, myths, and misconceptions == {{or-section|date=May 2018}} The underlying issues of sexual assault against LGBT persons includes homophobia and transphobia among other forms of prejudice against sexual minorities.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pcar.org/about-sexual-violence/lgbtq|title=LGBTQ {{!}} Pennsylvania Coalition Against Rape (PCAR)|website=www.pcar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-30}} These forms of prejudice end up creating unsafe spaces for LGBT persons where they do not feel comfortable expressing themselves or do not feel safe living as their authentic self. According to the [https://prideresourcecenter.colostate.edu/ Pride Resource Center] at Colorado State University, homophobia is defined as:
"Homophobia is a pervasive, irrational fear of homosexuality. Homophobia includes the fear heterosexuals have of any homosexual feelings within themselves, any overt mannerisms or actions that would suggest homosexuality, and the resulting desire to suppress or stamp out homosexuality. And it also includes the self-hatred and self-denial of homosexuals who know what they are but have been taught all their lives by a heterosexual society that people like themselves are sick, sinful and criminal.”{{Cite web|url=https://prideresourcecenter.colostate.edu/resources/homophobia/|title=Homophobia {{!}} Pride Resource Center|website=prideresourcecenter.colostate.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-06}}
According to [[Planned Parenthood]], transphobia is defined as:
"Transphobia is the fear, hatred, disbelief, or mistrust of people who are transgender, thought to be transgender, or whose gender expression doesn’t conform to traditional gender roles. Transphobia can prevent transgender and gender nonconforming people from living full lives free from harm."{{Cite web|url=https://www.plannedparenthood.org/learn/sexual-orientation-gender/trans-and-gender-nonconforming-identities/whats-transphobia|title=What's Transphobia? {{!}} Facts About Transphobic Discrimination|website=www.plannedparenthood.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-07}}
These phobias, as well as myths centered around LGBT individuals, influence a culture that holds back persons from identifying how they choose and places them into a binary that doesn't encompass all possible ways of identifying. One of the main myths that can harm LGBT individuals is the idea that they have not met the right guy/girl yet. This perpetuates heterosexism and denies the possibility of one having attraction to the same gender. One of the biggest misconceptions that comes out of transphobia centers around the use of bathrooms. Made popular by North Carolina's "[[Public Facilities Privacy & Security Act|Bathroom Bill]]", it brought up the concern that by allowing individuals to use the bathroom that corresponds to the gender they identify as, predators could easily enter bathrooms and take advantage of individuals claiming that they identify as the gender the bathroom is. Legislation, such as House Bill 2, only perpetuate the discrimination of transgender individuals, rather than give them support to live their lives as the gender by which they identify. Laws have always existed that prohibit individuals from entering bathrooms with the purpose of harming others.{{Cite news|url=http://www.glaad.org/sites/default/files/Debunking_the_Bathroom_Bill_Myth_2017.pdf|title=Debunking the "Bathroom Bill" Myth|last=|first=|date=|work=GLAAD Transgender Media Program|access-date=}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:LGBT rights]] [[Category:Sexual violence]] [[Category:Hate crime]] [[Category:Homophobia]] [[Category:Transphobia]] [[Category:Sexuality and society]] [[Category:Gender identity related violence]]

{{More citations needed|date=July 2012}} {{Sociology}} '''Social status''' is the relative respect, competence, and deference accorded to people, groups, and organizations in a society.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sauder|first1=Michael|last2=Lynn|first2=Freda|last3=Podolny|first3=Joel|title=Status: Insights from Organizational Sociology|journal=Annual Review of Sociology|date=2012|volume=38|pages=267–283|url=http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev-soc-071811-145503|doi=10.1146/annurev-soc-071811-145503}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Anderson|first1=Cameron|last2=Hildreth|first2=John|last3=Howland|first3=Laura|title=Is the Desire for Status a Fundamental Human Motive? A Review of the Empirical Literature|journal=Psychological Bulletin|date=2015|volume=141|issue=3|pages=574–601|doi=10.1037/a0038781|pmid=25774679}}</ref> Some writers have also referred to a socially valued role or category a person occupies as a "status" (e.g., being a criminal or mentally ill). At its core, status is about who members of a society consider to hold more social value.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sedikides | first1 = C. | last2 = Guinote | first2 = A. | year = 2018 | title = "How Status Shapes Social Cognition: Introduction to the Special Issue,"The Status of Status: Vistas from Social Cognition | url = | journal = Social Cognition | volume = 36 | issue = 1| pages = 1–3 | doi=10.1521/soco.2018.36.1.1}}</ref> These beliefs about who is more or less valued (e.g., honorable, respectable, smart) are broadly shared among members of a society.<ref>Simandan, D., 2018. Rethinking the health consequences of social class and social mobility. Social Science & Medicine. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.socscimed.2017.11.037 </ref> As such, people use status hierarchies to decide who gets to "call the shots," who is worthy, and who deserves access to valuable resources. In so doing, these shared cultural beliefs make unequal distributions of resources and [[Power (social and political)|power]] appear natural and fair, supporting systems of [[social stratification]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ridgeway|first1=Cecilia L.|last2=Correll|first2=Shelley|title=Consensus and the Creation of Status Beliefs.|journal=Social Forces|date=2006|volume=85|pages=431–453|url=https://academic.oup.com/sf/article-abstract/85/1/431/2235134|doi=10.1353/sof.2006.0139|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171022095315/https://academic.oup.com/sf/article-abstract/85/1/431/2235134|archivedate=2017-10-22|df=}}</ref> Status hierarchies appear to be universal across human societies, affording valued benefits to those who occupy the higher rungs, such as better health, social approval, resources, influence, and freedom.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Status hierarchies depend primarily on the possession and use of [[status symbols]]. These are cues people use to determine how much status a person holds and how they should be treated.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Goffman|first1=Erving|title=Symbols of Class Status|journal=British Journal of Sociology|date=1951|volume=2|issue=4|pages=294–304|doi=10.2307/588083|jstor=588083}}</ref> Such symbols can include possession of socially valuable attributes, like being conventionally beautiful or having a prestigious degree. Wealth and the display of it through [[conspicuous consumption]] can for instance be indicators of status.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Veblen|first1=Thornstein|title=The Theory of the Leisure Class: An Economic Study of Institutions|date=1899|publisher=MacMillan}}</ref> Status in face-to-face interaction can also be conveyed through certain controllable behaviors, such as assertive speech, posture,<ref>{{Citation|last=Mazur|first=Allan|title=A Biosocial Model of Status in Face-To-Face Groups|date=2015|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-12697-5_24|work=Evolutionary Perspectives on Social Psychology|pages=303–315|publisher=Springer International Publishing|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-12697-5_24|isbn=9783319126968|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref> and emotional displays.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tiedens|first=Larissa Z.|date=2001|title=Anger and advancement versus sadness and subjugation: The effect of negative emotion expressions on social status conferral.|url=https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.80.1.86|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=80|issue=1|pages=86–94|doi=10.1037//0022-3514.80.1.86|issn=0022-3514}}</ref>
==Determination==
Some perspectives on status emphasize its relatively fixed and fluid aspects. Ascribed statuses are fixed for an individual at birth, while achieved status is determined by social rewards an individual acquires during his or her lifetime as a result of the exercise of ability and/or perseverance.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Linton|first1=Ralph|title=The Study of Man|date=1936|publisher=Appleton Century Crofts}}</ref> Examples of ascribed status include [[caste]]s, [[Race (human categorization)|race]], and beauty among others. Meanwhile, achieved statuses are akin to one's educational credentials or occupation: these things require a person to exercise effort and often undergo years of training. The term [[master status]] has been used to describe the status most important for determining a person's position in a given context.<ref name="BrymLie2009">{{cite book|author1=Robert Brym|author2=John Lie|title=Sociology: Your Compass for a New World, Brief Edition: Enhanced Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vje_Pl5JmkcC&pg=PA88|date=11 June 2009|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=0-495-59893-3|page=88}}</ref><ref>Ferris, Kelly, and Jill Stein. [http://www.wwnorton.com/college/soc/real-world3/ch/04/ "The Self and Interaction."] Chapter 4 of ''The Real World: An Introduction to Sociology''. W. W. Norton & Company Inc, Dec. 2011. Accessed 20 September 2014.</ref>
== In different societies == Status refers to the relative rank that an individual holds; this includes attendant rights, duties, and lifestyle, in a [[social hierarchy]] based upon honor or [[wikt:prestige|prestige]]. Status has two different types that come along with it: achieved, and ascribed. The word status refers to social stratification on a vertical scale.
In modern societies, [[profession|occupation]] is usually thought of as the main determinant of status, but other memberships or affiliations (such as [[ethnic group]], [[religion]], [[gender]], voluntary associations, [[fandom]], [[hobby]]) can have an influence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.virginia.edu/topnews/textonlyarchive/September_1996/nerd.txt |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-04-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027083043/http://www.virginia.edu/topnews/textonlyarchive/September_1996/nerd.txt |archivedate=2007-10-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://yas.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/26/3/298 |title=The Effect of Middle School Extra Curricular Activities on Adolescents' Popularity and Peer Status – EDER and KINNEY 26 (3): 298 – Youth & Society |publisher=Yas.sagepub.com |date=1995-03-01 |accessdate=2014-05-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080703215724/http://yas.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/26/3/298 |archivedate=2008-07-03 |df= }}</ref> [[Achieved status]] is when people are placed in the stratification structure based on their individual merits or achievements. This status can be achieved through education, occupation, and marital status. Their place within the stratification structure is determined by society's bar, which often judges them on success, success being financial, academic, political and so on. America most commonly uses this form of status with jobs. The higher you are in rank the better off you are and the more control you have over your co-workers.
In pre-modern societies, status differentiation is widely varied. In some cases it can be quite rigid and class based, such as with the [[India]]n [[caste]] system. In other cases, status exists without class and/or informally, as is true with some [[Hunter-Gatherer]] societies such as the [[Khoisan]], and some [[Indigenous Australians|Indigenous Australian]] societies. In these cases, status is limited to specific personal relationships. For example, a [[Khoisan]] man is expected to take his wife's mother quite seriously (a non-joking relationship), although the mother-in-law has no special "status" over anyone except her son-in-law—and only then in specific contexts. All societies have a form of social status.
Status is an important idea in [[social stratification]]. [[Max Weber]] distinguishes status from [[social class]],<ref>Weber, Max. 1946. "Class, Status, Party." pp. 180–95 in From Max Weber: Essays in Sociology, H. H. Gerth and C. Wright Mills (eds.). New York: Oxford University.</ref> though some contemporary empirical sociologists combine the two ideas to create [[socioeconomic status]] or SES, usually operationalised as a simple [[Index (economics)|index]] of [[income]], [[education]] and occupational prestige.
== In nonhuman animals == Social status hierarchies have been documented in a wide range of animals: apes,<ref>Chimpanzee Politics (1982, 2007) deWaal, Frans, Johns Hopkins University Press</ref> baboons,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sapolsy | first1 = R.M. | year = | title = Cortisol concentrations and the social significance of rank instability among wild baboons | url = | journal = Journal of Psychoneuroendocrinology | volume = 17 | issue = | pages = 701–09 }}</ref> wolves,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freewebs.com/alphawolfsabrina/socialorderandvisual.htm|title=Accessed 10 September 2012|author=|date=|website=freewebs.com|accessdate=8 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506100134/http://www.freewebs.com/alphawolfsabrina/socialorderandvisual.htm|archivedate=6 May 2014|df=}}</ref> cows/bulls,<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1439-0310.1983.tb00087.x/abstract |title=Factors Influencing Dominance Status in American Bison Cows (Bison bison) |date= |accessdate=2014-05-24 |doi=10.1111/j.1439-0310.1983.tb00087.x |volume=63 |issue=2–3 |journal=Zeitschrift für Tierpsychologie |pages=206–212 |year=2010 | last1 = Rutberg | first1 = Allen T.}}</ref> hens,<ref>Schjelderup-Ebbe, T. 1922. Beitrage zurSozialpsycholgie des Haushuhns. ''Zeitschrift Psychologie'' 88: 225–52. Reprinted in Benchmark Papers in Animal Behaviour/3. Ed. M.W.Schein. 1975</ref> even fish,<ref>{{cite news |author=Natalie Angier |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/12/science/in-fish-social-status-goes-right-to-the-brain.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |title=In Fish, Social Status Goes Right to the Brain - New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1991-11-12 |accessdate=2014-05-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506094643/http://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/12/science/in-fish-social-status-goes-right-to-the-brain.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |archivedate=2014-05-06 |df= }}</ref> and ants.<ref>Wilson, E.O, The Insect Societies (1971) Belknap Press of Harvard University Press</ref> Natural selection produces status-seeking behavior because animals tend to have more surviving offspring when they raise their status in their social group.<ref>Wilson, E.O, Sociobiology (1975, 2000) Belknap Press of Harvard University Press</ref> Such behaviors vary widely because they are adaptations to a wide range of environmental niches. Some social [[dominance (ethology)|dominance]] behaviors tend to increase reproductive opportunity,<ref>Wrangham, R. and Peterson, D. (1996). Demonic males. Boston, MA: Houghton Mifflin. {{ISBN|978-0-395-87743-2}}.</ref> while others tend to raise the survival rates of an individual’s offspring.<ref>Smuts, B.B., Cheney, D.L. Seyfarth, R.M., Wrangham, R.W., & Struhsaker, T.T. (Eds.) (1987). Primate Societies. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. {{ISBN|0-226-76715-9}}</ref> Neurochemicals, particularly serotonin,<ref>{{cite journal | year = 1985 | title = Dominant social status facilitates the behavioral effects of serotonergic agonists | url = | journal = Brain Res | volume = 348 | issue = | pages = 274–82 | doi=10.1016/0006-8993(85)90445-7 | last1 = Raleigh | first1 = Michael J.}}</ref> prompt social dominance behaviors without need for an organism to have abstract conceptualizations of status as a means to an end. Social [[dominance hierarchy]] emerges from individual survival-seeking behaviors.
== Status inconsistency == {{Main|Status inconsistency}} Status inconsistency is a situation where an individual's [[social position]]s have both positive and negative influences on his or her social status. For example, a [[teacher]] may have a positive societal image (respect, prestige) which increases their status but may earn little [[money]], which simultaneously decreases their status.
== Inborn and acquired == [[File:Inquilinos.gif|thumb|right|250px|Social status is often associated with clothing and possessions. Compare the foreman with a horse and high hat with the [[inquilino]] in picture. Image from 19th century rural Chile.]] Statuses based on inborn characteristics, such as ethnicity, are called [[ascribed status]]es, while statuses that individuals gained through their own efforts are called [[achieved status]]es. Specific behaviors are associated with [[social stigma]]s, which can affect status.
Ascribed status is when one's position is inherited through family. [[Monarchy]] is a widely recognized use of this method, to keep the rulers in one family. This usually occurs at birth without any reference as to how that person may turn out to be a good or bad leader.
== Social mobility == Status can be changed through a process of [[social mobility]]. Social mobility is change of position within the stratification system. A move in status can be upward (upward mobility), or downward (downward mobility). Social mobility allows a person to move to another social status other than the one he or she was born in. Social mobility is more frequent in societies where achievement rather than ascription is the primary basis for social status.
Social mobility is especially prominent in the United States in the late 20th century, with an ever-increasing number of women entering into the workplace as well as a steady increase in the number of full-time college students.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.qualityinfo.org/olmisj/ArticleReader?itemid=00003582 |title=OLMIS – Women in the Labor Force |publisher=Qualityinfo.org |date= |accessdate=2014-05-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506101718/http://www.qualityinfo.org/olmisj/ArticleReader?itemid=00003582 |archivedate=2014-05-06 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d07/ |title=Digest of Education Statistics, 2007 - Introduction |publisher=Nces.ed.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-05-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506100227/http://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d07/ |archivedate=2014-05-06 |df= }}</ref> This increased education as well as the massive increase in multiple household incomes has greatly contributed to the rise in social mobility obtained by so many today. With this upward mobility; however, comes the philosophy of "[[Keeping up with the Joneses]]" that so many Americans obtain. Although this sounds good on the surface, it actually poses a problem because millions of Americans are in credit card debt due to [[conspicuous consumption]] and purchasing goods that they do not have the money to pay for.
== Social stratification == {{Main|Social stratification}} Social stratification describes the way people are placed or "stratified" in society. It is associated with the ability of individuals to live up to some set of ideals or principles regarded as important by the society or some social group within it. The members of a social group interact mainly within their own group and to a lesser degree with those of higher or lower status in a recognized system of social stratification. Such ties between people are often fluid and amorphous. Some of the more common bases for such ranking include:
Groups: * [[Wealth]]/[[Income]] (most common): Ties between persons with the same personal income * [[Gender]]: Ties between persons of the same sex and sexuality * Political status: Ties between persons of the same political views/status * [[Religion]]: Ties between persons of the same religion * [[Race (human classification)|Race]]/[[Ethnicity]]: Ties between persons of the same ethnic/racial group * [[Social class]]: Ties between persons born into the same economic group * [[Coolness]]: Ties between persons who have similar levels of [[popularity]]
== Max Weber's three dimensions of stratification == {{Main|Three-component theory of stratification}} The German sociologist [[Max Weber]] developed a theory proposing that stratification is based on three factors that have become known as "the three p's of stratification": [[property]], prestige and [[Power (sociology)|power]]. He claimed that [[social stratification]] is a result of the interaction of wealth (class), prestige status (or in German ''Stand'') and power (party).<ref>Tony Waters and Dagmar Waters, translators and eds., (2015). Weber's Rationalism and Modern Society. Palgrave Macmillan.</ref> * [[Reputation|Prestige]] is a significant factor in determining one's place in the stratification system. The ownership of property is not always going to assure power, but there are frequently people with prestige and little property. * [[Property]] refers to one's material possessions and their life chances. If someone has control of property, that person has power over others and can use the property to his or her own benefit. * [[Power (social and political)|Power]] is the ability to do what one wants, regardless of the will of others. (Domination, a closely related concept, is the power to make others' behavior conform to one's commands). This refers to two different types of power, which are possession of power and exercising power. For example, some people in charge of the government have an immense amount of power, and yet they do not make much money. Max Weber developed various ways that societies are organized in hierarchical systems of power. These ways are social status, class power and political power. * Class Power: This refers to unequal access to resources. If you have access to something that someone else needs, that can make you more powerful than the person in need. The person with the resource thus has bargaining power over the other. * Social Status (Social Power): If you view someone as a social superior, that person will have power over you because you believe that person has a higher status than you do. * Political Power: Political power can influence the hierarchical system of power because those that can influence what laws are passed and how they are applied can exercise power over others. There has been discussion about how Weber's three dimensions of stratification are more useful for specifying social inequality than more traditional terms like [[Socioeconomic Status]].<ref>Waters, Tony and Dagmar Waters 2016 Are the terms "socio-economic status" and "social status" a warped form of reasoning for Max Weber?" Palgrave Communications 2, Article number: 16002 (2016) {{cite web |url=http://www.palgrave-journals.com/articles/palcomms20162 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-04-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405132923/http://www.palgrave-journals.com/articles/palcomms20162 |archivedate=2016-04-05 |df= }}</ref>
=== Status group === {{Main|Status group}} [[Max Weber]] developed the idea of "status group" which is a translation of the German ''Stand'' (pl. ''Stände''). Status groups are communities that are based on ideas of lifestyles and the honor the status group both asserts, and is given by others. Status groups exist in the context of beliefs about relative prestige, privilege, and honor and can be of both a positive and negative sort. People in status groups are only supposed to engage with people of like status, and in particular, marriage inside or outside the group is discouraged. Status groups can include professions, club-like organizations, ethnicity, race, and other groups for which pattern association.<ref>Weber 48-56</ref>
== Pierre Bourdieu's theory on class distinction == The French sociologist [[Pierre Bourdieu]] developed theories of [[social stratification]] based on aesthetic taste in his work ''[[La Distinction|Distinction]]''. Bourdieu claims that how one chooses to present one's social space to the world, one's aesthetic dispositions, depicts one's status and distances oneself from lower groups. Specifically, Bourdieu hypothesizes that these dispositions are internalized at an early age and guide the young towards their appropriate social positions, towards the behaviors that are suitable for them, and an aversion towards other lifestyles.
Bourdieu theorizes that class fractions teach aesthetic preferences to their young. Class fractions are determined by a combination of the varying degrees of social, economic, and [[cultural capital]]. Society incorporates "symbolic goods, especially those regarded as the attributes of excellence, […as] the ideal weapon in strategies of distinction".<ref name="Bourdieu 66">Bourdieu 66</ref> Those attributes deemed excellent are shaped by the interests of the dominating class. He emphasizes the dominance of cultural capital early on by stating that "differences in cultural capital mark the differences between the classes".<ref name="Bourdieu 69">Bourdieu 69</ref>
Aesthetic dispositions are the result of social origin rather than accumulated capital and experience over time. The acquisition of [[cultural capital]] depends heavily on "[t]otal, early, imperceptible learning, performed within the family from the earliest days of life".<ref name="Bourdieu 66" /> Bourdieu hypothetically guarantees that the opinions of the young are those that they are born into, the accepted "definitions that their elders offer them".<ref name="Bourdieu 477">Bourdieu 477</ref>
He asserts the primacy of social origin and [[cultural capital]] by claiming that [[social capital]] and [[economic capital]], though acquired cumulatively over time, depend upon it. Bourdieu claims that "one has to take account of all the characteristics of social condition which are (statistically) associated from earliest childhood with possession of high or low income and which tend to shape tastes adjusted to these conditions".<ref name="Bourdieu 177">Bourdieu 177</ref>
According to Bourdieu, tastes in food, culture and presentation, are indicators of class, because trends in their consumption seemingly correlate with an individual's fit in society.<ref name="Bourdieu 144">Bourdieu 184</ref> Each fraction of the dominant class develops its own aesthetic criteria. A multitude of consumer interests based on differing social positions necessitates that each fraction "has its own artists and philosophers, newspapers and critics, just as it has its hairdresser, interior decorator or tailor."<ref name="Bourdieu 231">Bourdieu 231–32</ref>
Bourdieu does not wholly disregard the importance of [[social capital]] and [[economic capital]] in the formation of [[cultural capital]]. In fact, the production of art and the ability to play an instrument "presuppose not only dispositions associated with long establishment in the world of art and culture but also economic means…and spare time".<ref name="Bourdieu 75">Bourdieu 75</ref> However, regardless of one's ability to act upon one's preferences, Bourdieu specifies that "respondents are only required to express a status-induced familiarity with legitimate... culture".<ref name="Bourdieu 63">Bourdieu 63</ref>
"[Taste] functions as a sort of social orientation, a 'sense of one's place', guiding the occupants of a given... social space towards the social positions adjusted to their properties, and towards the practices or goods which befit the occupants of that position".<ref name="Bourdieu 466">Bourdieu 466</ref> Thus, different modes of acquisition yield differences in the nature of preferences.<ref name="Bourdieu 65">Bourdieu 65</ref>
These "cognitive structures…are internalized, 'embodied' social structures", becoming a natural entity to the individual.<ref name="Bourdieu 468">Bourdieu 468</ref> Different tastes are thus seen as unnatural and rejected, resulting in "disgust provoked by horror or visceral intolerance ('sick-making') of the tastes of others."<ref name="Bourdieu 56">Bourdieu 56</ref>
Bourdieu himself believes class distinction and preferences are "most marked in the ordinary choices of everyday existence, such as furniture, clothing or cooking, which are particularly revealing of deep-rooted and long-standing dispositions because, lying outside the scope of the educational system, they have to be confronted, as it were, by naked taste".<ref name="Bourdieu 77">Bourdieu 77</ref> Indeed, Bordieu believes that "the strongest and most indelible mark of infant learning" would probably be in the tastes of food.<ref name="Bourdieu 79">Bourdieu 79</ref> Bourdieu thinks that meals served on special occasions are "an interesting indicator of the mode of self-presentation adopted in 'showing off' a life-style (in which furniture also plays a part)".<ref name="Bourdieu 79" /> The idea is that their likes and dislikes should mirror those of their class fractions.
Children from the lower end of the social hierarchy are predicted to choose "heavy, fatty fattening foods, which are also cheap" in their dinner layouts, opting for "plentiful and good" meals as opposed to foods that are "original and exotic".<ref name="Bourdieu 177" /><ref name="Bourdieu 79" /> These potential outcomes would reinforce Bourdieu's "ethic of sobriety for the sake of slimness, which is most recognized at the highest levels of the social hierarchy," that contrasts the "convivial indulgence" characteristic of the lower classes.<ref name="Bourdieu 179">Bourdieu 179</ref> Demonstrations of the tastes of luxury (or freedom) and the tastes of necessity reveal a distinction among the [[social class]]es.
The degree to which social origin affects these preferences surpasses both educational and economic capital. In fact, at equivalent levels of [[educational capital]], social origin remains an influential factor in determining these dispositions.<ref name="Bourdieu 63" /> How one describes one's social environment relates closely to social origin because the instinctive narrative springs from early stages of development.<ref name="Bourdieu 78">Bourdieu 78</ref> Also, across the divisions of labor "economic constraints tend to relax without any fundamental change in the pattern of spending".<ref name="Bourdieu 185">Bourdieu 185</ref> This observation reinforces the idea that social origin, more than economic capital, produces aesthetic preferences because regardless of economic capability consumption patterns remain stable.

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} In [[mathematics]], progress often consists of recognising the same '''structure''' in different contexts, so that one method exploiting it has multiple applications. In fact this is a normal way of proceeding; in the absence of recognisable structure (which might be hidden) problems tend to fall into the [[combinatorics]] classification of matters requiring special arguments.
In [[category theory]] ''structure'' is discussed ''implicitly'' — as opposed to the ''explicit'' discussion typical with the many [[algebraic structure]]s. Starting with a given class of algebraic structure, such as [[group (mathematics)|group]]s, one can build the category in which the objects are groups and the [[morphism]]s are [[group homomorphism]]s: that is, of structures on one type, and mappings respecting that structure. Starting with a category ''C'' given abstractly, the challenge is to infer what structure it is on the objects that the morphisms 'preserve'.
The term ''structure'' was much used in connection with the [[Nicolas Bourbaki|Bourbaki]] group's approach. There is even a definition. Structure must definitely include [[topological space]] as well as the standard [[abstract algebra]] notions. Structure in this sense is probably commensurate with the idea of [[concrete category]] that can be presented in a definite way — the topological case means that infinitary operations will be needed. ''Presentation of a category'' (analogously to [[presentation of a group]]) can in fact be approached in a number of ways, the ''category'' structure not being (quite) an algebraic structure in its own right.
The term ''transport of structure'' is the 'French' way of expressing ''covariance'' or ''equivariance'' as a constraint: transfer structure by a [[surjection]] and then (if there is an existing structure) compare.
Since any group is a one-object category, a special case of the question about ''what the morphisms preserve'' is this: how to consider any group G as a [[symmetry group]]? That is answered, as best we can by [[Cayley's theorem]]. The analogue in category theory is the [[Yoneda lemma]]. One concludes that knowledge on the 'structure' is bound up with what we can say about the [[representable functor]]s on ''C''. Characterisations of them, in interesting cases, were sought in the 1960s, for application in particular in the [[moduli problem]]s of [[algebraic geometry]]; showing in fact that these are very subtle matters.

{{BLPsources|date=October 2011}} '''Tadesse Meskela''' is the General Manager of the [[Oromia Coffee Farmers Cooperative Union]] of Ethiopia and was featured in the documentary ''[[Black Gold (2006 film)|Black Gold]]''. He is a proponent of [[Fair trade|fair-trade]], and speaks publicly in support of it around the world.
He grew up in the countryside outside Addis Ababa, Bishoftu. Tadesse Meskela studied his way out of poverty and eventually made it to university. By the early 1990s he was working for the state Agricultural Bureau. He attended a two-month co-operative training placement in Japan and was inspired to develop a cooperative union system to help Ethiopian coffee farmers attain a fairer recompense for their produce. The Oromia Coffee Farmers Co-operative Union was established in 1999. In the year 2004, the union has facilitated the constructed of four new schools, seventeen additional classrooms, four health centres, two clean water supply stations, and in terms of dividends, $2 million has been given back to the farmers.

In [[multilinear algebra]], the '''tensor rank decomposition''' or '''canonical polyadic decomposition (CPD)''' may be regarded as a generalization of the matrix [[singular value decomposition]] (SVD) to [[Tensor (intrinsic definition)|tensor]]s, which has found application in [[statistics]], [[signal processing]], [[psychometrics]], [[linguistics]] and [[chemometrics]]. It was introduced by [[Frank Lauren Hitchcock|Hitchcock]] in 1927<ref>{{Cite journal | author = [[F. L. Hitchcock]] | title = The expression of a tensor or a polyadic as a sum of products | journal = [[Journal of Mathematics and Physics]] | volume = 6 | pages = 164–189 | year = 1927 }}</ref> and later rediscovered several times, notably in psychometrics.<ref name="cc1970">{{Cite journal | first1 = J. D. | last1 = Carroll | authorlink1 = J. D. Carroll | first2 = J. | last2 = Chang | authorlink2 = J. Chang | title = Analysis of individual differences in multidimensional scaling via an ''n''-way generalization of 'Eckart–Young' decomposition | journal = [[Psychometrika]] | volume = 35 | pages = 283–319 | year = 1970 | doi = 10.1007/BF02310791 }}</ref><ref name="h1970">{{cite journal|first=Richard A. |last=Harshman |authorlink=Richard A. Harshman |year=1970 |url=http://publish.uwo.ca/~harshman/wpppfac0.pdf |title=Foundations of the PARAFAC procedure: Models and conditions for an "explanatory" multi-modal factor analysis |journal=UCLA Working Papers in Phonetics |volume=16 |pages=84 |publisher=[[University Microfilms]] |location=[[Ann Arbor]] |id=No. 10,085 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041010092429/http://publish.uwo.ca/~harshman/wpppfac0.pdf |archivedate=October 10, 2004 }}</ref> For this reason, the tensor rank decomposition is sometimes historically referred to as PARAFAC<ref name="h1970" /> or CANDECOMP.<ref name="cc1970" />
The tensor rank decomposition expresses a tensor as a minimum-length linear combination of '''rank-1 tensors'''. Such rank-1 tensors are also called '''simple''' or '''pure'''. A pure tensor is the [[tensor product]] of a collection of vectors.
== Definition ==
Consider a tensor space <math>F^{n_1 \times \cdots \times n_d} \cong F^{n_1} \otimes \cdots \otimes F^{n_d}</math>, where <math>F</math> is either the real field <math>\mathbb{R}</math> or the complex field <math>\mathbb{C}</math>. Every (order-<math>d</math>) tensor in this space may then be represented with a suitably large <math>r</math> as a linear combination of <math>r</math> rank-1 tensors:
: <math>\mathcal{A} = \sum_{i=1}^{r} \lambda_i \mathbf{a}_i^1 \otimes \mathbf{a}_i^2 \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathbf{a}_i^d,</math>
where <math>\lambda_i \in F</math> and <math>\mathbf{a}_i^k \in F^{n_k}</math>; note that the superscript <math>k</math> should not be interpreted as an exponent, it is merely another index. When the number of terms <math>r</math> is minimal in the above expression, then <math>r</math> is called the '''rank''' of the tensor, and the decomposition is often referred to as a ''(tensor) rank decomposition'', ''minimal CP decomposition'', or ''Canonical Polyadic Decomposition (CPD)''. Contrariwise, if the number of terms is not minimal, then the above decomposition is often referred to as ''<math>r</math>-term decomposition'', ''CANDECOMP/PARAFAC'' or ''Polyadic decomposition''.
== Tensor rank ==
Contrary to the case of matrices, the rank of a tensor is presently not understood well. It is known that the problem of computing the rank of a tensor is [[NP-hard]].<ref>{{Cite journal | first1 = C. J. | last1 = Hillar | authorlink1 = C. J. Hillar | first2 = L. | last2 = Lim | authorlink2 = L. Lim | title = Most tensor problems are NP-Hard | journal = Journal of the ACM | volume = 60 | year = 2013 | pages = 45 | doi=10.1145/2512329| arxiv = 0911.1393 }}</ref> The only notable well-understood case consists of tensors in <math>F^{m} \otimes F^{n} \otimes F^2</math>, whose rank can be obtained from the [[Leopold Kronecker|Kronecker]]–[[Weierstrass]] normal form of the linear [[matrix pencil]] that the tensor represents.<ref>{{Cite book | first1 = J. M. | last1 = Landsberg | authorlink1 = J. M. Landsberg | title = Tensors: Geometry and Applications | publisher = AMS | year = 2012}}</ref> A simple polynomial-time algorithm exists for certifying that a tensor is of rank 1, namely the [[higher-order singular value decomposition]].
The rank of the tensor of zeros is zero by convention. The rank of a tensor <math>\mathbf{a}_1 \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathbf{a}_d </math> is one, provided that <math> \mathbf{a}_k \in F^{n_k}\setminus\{0\} </math>.
=== Field dependence === The rank of a tensor depends on the field over which the tensor is decomposed. It is known that some real tensors may admit a complex decomposition whose rank is strictly less than the rank of a real decomposition of the same tensor. As an example,<ref name="dSL2008" /> consider the following real tensor
: <math> \mathcal{A} = \mathbf{x}_1 \otimes \mathbf{x}_2 \otimes \mathbf{x}_3 + \mathbf{x}_1 \otimes \mathbf{y}_2 \otimes \mathbf{y}_3 - \mathbf{y}_1 \otimes \mathbf{x}_2 \otimes \mathbf{y}_3 + \mathbf{y}_1 \otimes \mathbf{y}_2 \otimes \mathbf{x}_3, </math>
where <math>\mathbf{x}_i, \mathbf{y}_j \in \mathbb{R}^2</math>. The rank of this tensor over the reals is known to be 3, while its complex rank is only 2 because it is the sum of a complex rank-1 tensor with its [[complex conjugate]], namely
: <math> \mathcal{A} = \frac{1}{2}( \bar{\mathbf{z}}_1 \otimes \mathbf{z}_2 \otimes \bar{\mathbf{z}}_3 + \mathbf{z}_1 \otimes \bar{\mathbf{z}}_2 \otimes \mathbf{z}_3),</math>
where <math> \mathbf{z}_k=\mathbf{x}_k + i\mathbf{y}_k</math>.
In contrast, the rank of real matrices will never decrease under a [[field extension]] to <math>\mathbb{C}</math>: real matrix rank and complex matrix rank coincide for real matrices.
=== Generic rank === The '''generic rank''' <math>r(n_1,\ldots,n_d)</math> is defined as the least rank <math>r</math> such that the closure in the [[Zariski topology]] of the set of tensors of rank at most <math>r</math> is the entire space <math>F^{n_1} \otimes \cdots \otimes F^{n_d}</math>. In the case of complex tensors, tensors of rank at most <math>r(n_1,\ldots,n_d)</math> form a [[dense set]] <math>S</math>: every tensor in the aforementioned space is either of rank less than the generic rank, or it is the limit in the [[Euclidean topology]] of a sequence of tensors from <math>S</math>. In the case of real tensors, the set of tensors of rank at most <math>r(n_1,\ldots,n_d)</math> only forms an open set of positive measure in the Euclidean topology. There may exist Euclidean-open sets of tensors of rank strictly higher than the generic rank. All ranks appearing on open sets in the Euclidean topology are called '''typical ranks'''. The smallest typical rank is called the generic rank; this definition applies to both complex and real tensors. The generic rank of tensor spaces was initially studied in 1983 by [[Volker Strassen]].<ref>{{Cite journal | first1 = V. | last1 = Strassen | authorlink1 = Volker Strassen | title = Rank and optimal computation of generic tensors | journal = [[Linear Algebra and its Applications]] | year = 1983 | volume = 52/53 | pages = 645–685 | doi=10.1016/0024-3795(83)80041-x}}</ref>
As an illustration of the above concepts, it is known that both 2 and 3 are typical ranks of <math>\mathbb{R}^2 \otimes \mathbb{R}^2 \otimes \mathbb{R}^2</math> while the generic rank of <math>\mathbb{C}^2 \otimes \mathbb{C}^2 \otimes \mathbb{C}^2</math> is 2. Practically, this means that a randomly sampled real tensor (from a continuous probability measure on the space of tensors) of size <math>2 \times 2 \times 2</math> will be a rank-1 tensor with probability zero, a rank-2 tensor with positive probability, and rank-3 with positive probability. On the other hand, a randomly sampled complex tensor of the same size will be a rank-1 tensor with probability zero, a rank-2 tensor with probability one, and a rank-3 tensor with probability zero. It is even known that the generic rank-3 real tensor in <math>\mathbb{R}^2 \otimes \mathbb{R}^2 \otimes \mathbb{R}^2</math> will be of complex rank equal to 2.
The generic rank of tensor spaces depends on the distinction between balanced and unbalanced tensor spaces. A tensor space <math>F^{n_1} \otimes \cdots \otimes F^{n_d}</math>, where <math>n_1 \ge n_2 \ge \cdots \ge n_d</math>, is called '''unbalanced''' whenever
: <math>n_1 > 1 + \prod_{k=2}^d n_k - \sum_{k=2}^d (n_k-1), </math>
and it is called '''balanced''' otherwise.
==== Unbalanced tensor spaces ==== When the first factor is very large with respect to the other factors in the tensor product, then the tensor space essentially behaves as a matrix space. The generic rank of tensors living in an unbalanced tensor spaces is known to equal
: <math> r(n_1,\ldots,n_d) = \min\left\{ n_1, \prod_{k=2}^d n_k \right\} </math>
[[almost everywhere]]. More precisely, the rank of every tensor in an unbalanced tensor space <math>F^{n_1 \times \cdots \times n_d} \setminus Z</math>, where <math>Z</math> is some indeterminate closed set in the Zariski topology, equals the above value.<ref>{{Cite journal | first1 = M. V. | last1 = Catalisano | authorlink1 = M. V. Catalisano | first2 = A. V. | last2 = Geramita | authorlink2 = A. V. Geramita | first3 = A. | last3 = Gimigliano | authorlink3 = A. Gimigliano | title = Ranks of tensors, secant varieties of Segre varieties and fat points | journal = [[Linear Algebra and its Applications]] | volume = 355 | pages = 263–285 | year = 2002 | doi=10.1016/s0024-3795(02)00352-x }}</ref>
==== Balanced tensor spaces ==== The generic rank of tensors living in a balanced tensor space is '''expected''' to equal
: <math> r_E(n_1,\ldots,n_d) = \left\lceil \frac{\Pi}{\Sigma+1} \right\rceil </math>
[[almost everywhere]] for complex tensors and on a Euclidean-open set for real tensors, where
: <math> \Pi = \prod_{k=1}^{d} n_k \quad\text{and}\quad \Sigma = \sum_{k=1}^{d} (n_k - 1). </math>
More precisely, the rank of every tensor in <math>\mathbb{C}^{n_1 \times \cdots \times n_d} \setminus Z</math>, where <math>Z</math> is some indeterminate closed set in the [[Zariski topology]], is expected to equal the above value.<ref name="aop2009">{{Cite journal | first1 = H. | last1 = Abo | authorlink1 = H. Abo | first2 = G. | last2 = Ottaviani | authorlink2 = G. Ottaviani | first3 = C. | last3 = Peterson | authorlink3 = C. Peterson | title = Induction for secant varieties of Segre varieties | journal = [[Transactions of the American Mathematical Society]] | volume = 361 | pages = 767–792 | year = 2009 | doi=10.1090/s0002-9947-08-04725-9 | arxiv = math/0607191}}</ref> For real tensors, <math>r_E(n_1,\ldots,n_d)</math> is the least rank that is expected to occur on a set of positive Euclidean measure. The value <math>r_E(n_1,\ldots,n_d)</math> is often referred to as the '''expected generic rank''' of the tensor space <math>F^{n_1 \times \cdots \times n_d}</math> because it is only conjecturally correct. It is known that the true generic rank always satisfies
: <math> r(n_1, \ldots, n_d) \ge r_E(n_1, \ldots, n_d). </math>
The '''Abo–Ottaviani–Peterson conjecture'''<ref name="aop2009" /> states that equality is expected, i.e., <math>r(n_1,\ldots,n_d) = r_E(n_1,\ldots,n_d)</math>, with the following exceptional cases:
* <math> F^{4 \times 4 \times 3}</math> * <math> F^{(2n+1) \times (2n+1) \times 3} \text{ with } n = 1, 2, \ldots</math> * <math> F^{(n+1) \times (n+1) \times 2 \times 2} \text{ with } n = 1, 2, \ldots</math>
In each of these exceptional cases, the generic rank is known to be <math>r(n_1,\ldots,n_d) = r_E(n_1,\ldots,n_d)+1</math>. The conjecture has been proved completely in a number of special cases. Lickteig showed already in 1985 that <math>r(n,n,n) = r_E(n,n,n)</math>, provided that <math>n \ne 3</math>.<ref>{{Cite journal | first1 = Thomas | last1 = Lickteig | authorlink1 = T. Lickteig | title = Typical tensorial rank | journal = [[Linear Algebra and its Applications]] | year = 1985 | volume = 69 | pages = 95–120 | doi=10.1016/0024-3795(85)90070-9}}</ref> In 2011, a major breakthrough was established by Catalisano, Geramita, and Gimigliano who proved that <math>r(2,2,\ldots,2) = r_E(2,2,\ldots,2)</math>, except for the space <math>F^2 \otimes F^2 \otimes F^2 \otimes F^2</math>.<ref>{{Cite journal | first1 = M. V. | last1 = Catalisano | authorlink1 = M. V. Catalisano | first2 = A. V. | last2 = Geramita | authorlink2 = A. V. Geramita | first3 = A. | last3 = Gimigliano | authorlink3 = A. Gimigliano | title = Secant varieties of ℙ<sup>1</sup> × ··· × ℙ<sup>1</sup> (''n''-times) are not defective for ''n'' ≥ 5 | journal = Journal of Algebraic Geometry | year = 2011 | volume = 20 | pages = 295–327 | doi=10.1090/s1056-3911-10-00537-0}}</ref>
=== Maximum rank ===
The '''maximum rank''' that can be admitted by any of the tensors in a tensor space is unknown in general; even a conjecture about this maximum rank is missing. Presently, the best general upper bound states that the maximum rank <math>r_M(n_1,\ldots,n_d)</math> of <math>F^{n_1} \otimes \cdots \otimes F^{n_d}</math>, where <math>n_1 \ge n_2 \ge \cdots \ge n_d</math>, satisfies
: <math>r_M(n_1,\ldots,n_d) \le \min\left\{ \prod_{k=2}^d n_k, 2 \cdot r(n_1,\ldots,n_d) \right\},</math>
where <math>r(n_1,\ldots,n_d)</math> is the (least) ''generic rank'' of <math>F^{n_1} \otimes \cdots \otimes F^{n_d}</math>.<ref>{{Cite journal | first1 = G. | last1 = Blehkerman | authorlink1 = G. Blehkerman | first2 = Z. | last2 = Teitler | authorlink2 = Z. Teitler | title = On maximum, typical and generic ranks | journal = [[Mathematische Annalen]] | volume = In press. | pages = 1–11 | year = 2014 | doi = 10.1007/s00208-014-1150-3 | arxiv = 1402.2371}}</ref> It is well-known that the foregoing inequality may be strict. For instance, the generic rank of tensors in <math>\mathbb{R}^{2\times 2 \times 2}</math> is two, so that the above bound yields <math>r_M(2,2,2) \le 4</math>, while it is known that the maximum rank equals 3.<ref name="dSL2008">{{Cite journal | first1 = V. | last1 = de Silva | authorlink1 = V. de Silva | first2 = L. | last2 = Lim | authorlink2 = L. Lim | title = Tensor Rank and the Ill-Posedness of the Best Low-Rank Approximation Problem | journal = [[SIAM Journal on Matrix Analysis and Applications]] | volume = 30 | pages = 1084–1127 | year = 2008 | doi=10.1137/06066518x | arxiv = math/0607647}}</ref>
=== Border rank ===
A rank-<math>s</math> tensor <math>\mathcal{A}</math> is called a '''border tensor''' if there exists a sequence of tensors of rank at most <math>r < s</math> whose limit is <math>\mathcal{A}</math>. If <math>s</math> is the least value for which such a convergent sequence exists, then it is called the '''border rank''' of <math>\mathcal{A}</math>. For order-2 tensors, i.e., matrices, rank and border rank ''always'' coincide, however, for tensors of order <math>\ge3</math> they may differ. Border tensors were first studied in the context of fast ''approximate'' [[matrix multiplication algorithm]]s by Bini, Lotti, and Romani in 1980.<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Approximate solutions for the bilinear form computational problem | journal = [[SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing]] | first1 = D. | last1 = Bini | authorlink1 = D. Bini | first2 = G. | last2 = Lotti | authorlink2 = G. Lotti | first3 = F. | last3 = Romani | authorlink3 = F. Romani | volume = 9 | pages = 692–697 | year = 1980 | doi=10.1137/0209053}}</ref>
A classic example of a border tensor is the rank-3 tensor
: <math>\mathcal{A} = \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{v} + \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{v} \otimes \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{v} \otimes \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{u}, \quad \text{with } \|\mathbf{u}\| = \|\mathbf{v}\| = 1 \text{ and } \langle \mathbf{u}, \mathbf{v}\rangle \ne 1.</math>
It can be approximated arbitrarily well by the following sequence of rank-2 tensors
: <math>\begin{align} \mathcal{A}_n &= n (\mathbf{u} + \frac{1}{n} \mathbf{v}) \otimes (\mathbf{u} + \frac{1}{n} \mathbf{v}) \otimes (\mathbf{u} + \frac{1}{n} \mathbf{v}) - n \mathbf{u}\otimes\mathbf{u}\otimes\mathbf{u} \\ &= \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{v} + \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{v} \otimes \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{v} \otimes \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{u} + \frac{1}{n} (\mathbf{u}\otimes\mathbf{v}\otimes\mathbf{v} + \mathbf{v}\otimes\mathbf{u}\otimes\mathbf{v} + \mathbf{v}\otimes\mathbf{v}\otimes\mathbf{u}) + \frac{1}{n^2} \mathbf{v}\otimes\mathbf{v}\otimes\mathbf{v} \end{align}</math>
as <math>n \to \infty</math>. Therefore, its border rank is 2, which is strictly less than its rank. When the two vectors are orthogonal, this example is also known as a [[W state]].
== Properties ==
=== Identifiability === It follows from the definition of a pure tensor that <math>\mathcal{A} = \mathbf{a}^1 \otimes \mathbf{a}^2 \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathbf{a}^d = \mathbf{b}^1 \otimes \mathbf{b}^2 \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathbf{b}^d</math> if and only if there exist <math>\lambda_k</math> such that <math>\lambda_1 \lambda_2 \cdots \lambda_k = 1</math> and <math>\mathbf{a}^k = \lambda_k \mathbf{b}^k</math> for all ''k''. For this reason, the parameters <math>\{ \mathbf{a}^k \}_{k=1}^d</math> of a rank-1 tensor <math>\mathcal{A}</math> are called identifiable or essentially unique. A rank-<math>r</math> tensor <math>\mathcal{A} \in F^{n_1} \otimes F^{n_2} \otimes \cdots \otimes F^{n_d}</math> is called '''identifiable''' if every of its tensor rank decompositions is the sum of the same set of <math>r</math> distinct tensors <math>\{ \mathcal{A}_1, \mathcal{A}_2, \ldots, \mathcal{A}_r \}</math> where the <math>\mathcal{A}_i</math>'s are of rank 1. An identifiable rank-<math>r</math> thus has only one essentially unique decomposition <math display="block">\mathcal{A} = \sum_{i=1}^r \mathcal{A}_i,</math>and all <math>r!</math> tensor rank decompositions of <math>\mathcal{A}</math> can be obtained by permuting the order of the summands. Observe that in a tensor rank decomposition all the <math>\mathcal{A}_i</math>'s are distinct, for otherwise the rank of <math>\mathcal{A}</math> would be at most <math>r-1</math>.
==== Generic identifiability ==== Order-2 tensors in <math>F^{n_1} \otimes F^{n_2} \simeq F^{n_1 \times n_2}</math>, i.e., matrices, are not identifiable for <math>r > 1</math>. This follows essentially from the observation <math display="block">\mathcal{A} = \sum_{i=1}^r \mathbf{a}_i \otimes \mathbf{b}_i = \sum_{i=1}^r \mathbf{a}_i \mathbf{b}_i^T = A B^T = (A X^{-1}) (B X^T)^T = \sum_{i=1}^r \mathbf{c}_i \mathbf{d}_i^T = \sum_{i=1}^r \mathbf{c}_i \otimes \mathbf{d}_i,</math>where <math>X \in \mathrm{GL}_{r}(F)</math> is an invertible <math>r \times r</math> matrix, <math>A = [\mathbf{a}_i]_{i=1}^r</math> , <math>B = [\mathbf{b}_i]_{i=1}^r</math>, <math>A X^{-1} = [\mathbf{c}_i]_{i=1}^r</math> and <math>B X^T = [\mathbf{d}_i]_{i=1}^r</math>. It can be shown<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/10.1007/978-1-4757-2189-8|title=Algebraic Geometry {{!}} SpringerLink|last=Harris|first=Joe|language=en-gb|doi=10.1007/978-1-4757-2189-8}}</ref> that for every <math>X \in \mathrm{GL}_n(F)\setminus Z</math>, where <math>Z</math> is a closed set in the Zariski topology, the decomposition on the right-hand side is a sum of a different set of rank-1 tensors than the decomposition on the left-hand side, entailing that order-2 tensors of rank <math>r>1</math> are generically not identifiable.
The situation changes completely for higher-order tensors in <math>F^{n_1} \otimes F^{n_2} \otimes \cdots \otimes F^{n_d}</math> with <math>d > 2</math> and all <math>n_i \ge 2</math>. For simplicity in notation, assume without loss of generality that the factors are ordered such that <math>n_1 \ge n_2 \ge \cdots \ge n_d \ge 2</math>. Let <math>S_r \subset F^{n_1} \otimes \cdots \otimes F^{n_d}</math>denote the set of tensors of rank bounded by <math>r</math>. Then, the following statement was proved to be correct using a [[computer-assisted proof]] for all spaces of dimension <math>\Pi < 15000 </math>,<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Chiantini|first=L.|last2=Ottaviani|first2=G.|last3=Vannieuwenhoven|first3=N.|date=2014-01-01|title=An Algorithm For Generic and Low-Rank Specific Identifiability of Complex Tensors|url=http://epubs.siam.org/doi/10.1137/140961389|journal=SIAM Journal on Matrix Analysis and Applications|volume=35|issue=4|pages=1265–1287|doi=10.1137/140961389|issn=0895-4798}}</ref> and it is conjectured to be valid in general:<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bocci|first=Cristiano|last2=Chiantini|first2=Luca|last3=Ottaviani|first3=Giorgio|date=2014-12-01|title=Refined methods for the identifiability of tensors|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10231-013-0352-8|journal=Annali di Matematica Pura ed Applicata (1923 -)|language=en|volume=193|issue=6|pages=1691–1702|doi=10.1007/s10231-013-0352-8|issn=0373-3114}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chiantini|first=L.|last2=Ottaviani|first2=G.|last3=Vannieuwenhoven|first3=N.|date=2017-01-01|title=Effective Criteria for Specific Identifiability of Tensors and Forms|url=http://epubs.siam.org/doi/10.1137/16M1090132|journal=SIAM Journal on Matrix Analysis and Applications|volume=38|issue=2|pages=656–681|doi=10.1137/16m1090132|issn=0895-4798}}</ref>
There exists a closed set <math>Z_r</math> in the Zariski topology such that ''every tensor'' <math>\mathcal{A} \in S_r\setminus Z_r</math>''is identifiable'' (<math>S_r</math> is called '''generically identifiable''' in this case), unless either one of the following exceptional cases holds: # The rank is too large: <math>r > r_E(n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_d)</math>; # The space is identifiability-unbalanced, i.e., <math display="inline">n_1 > \prod_{k=2}^d n_k - \sum_{k=2}^d (n_k - 1)</math>, and the rank is too large: <math display="inline">r \ge \prod_{k=2}^d n_k - \sum_{k=2}^d (n_k-1)</math>; # The space is the defective case <math>F^4 \otimes F^4 \otimes F^3</math> and the rank is <math>r=5</math>; # The space is the defective case <math>F^n \otimes F^n \otimes F^2 \otimes F^2</math>, where <math>n \ge 2</math>, and the rank is <math>r = 2n-1</math>; # The space is <math>F^4 \otimes F^4 \otimes F^4</math> and the rank is <math>r=6</math>; # The space is <math>F^6 \otimes F^6 \otimes F^3</math> and the rank is <math>r = 8</math>; or # The space is <math>F^2 \otimes F^2 \otimes F^2 \otimes F^2 \otimes F^2</math> and the rank is <math>r=5</math>. # The space is perfect, i.e., <math display="inline">r_E(n_1,n_2,\ldots,n_d) = \frac{\Pi}{\Sigma+1}</math> is an integer, and the rank is <math display="inline">r = r_E(n_1,n_2,\ldots,n_d)</math>. In these exceptional cases, the generic (and also minimum) number of ''complex'' decompositions is * proved to be <math>\infty </math> in the first 4 cases; * proved to be two in case 5;<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chiantini|first=L.|last2=Ottaviani|first2=G.|date=2012-01-01|title=On Generic Identifiability of 3-Tensors of Small Rank|url=http://epubs.siam.org/doi/10.1137/110829180|journal=SIAM Journal on Matrix Analysis and Applications|volume=33|issue=3|pages=1018–1037|doi=10.1137/110829180|issn=0895-4798}}</ref> * expected<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Hauenstein|first=J. D.|last2=Oeding|first2=L.|last3=Ottaviani|first3=G.|last4=Sommese|first4=A. J.|date=|title=Homotopy techniques for tensor decomposition and perfect identifiability|url=https://doi.org/10.1515/crelle-2016-0067|journal=J. Reine Angew. Math.|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> to be six in case 6; * proved to be two in case 7;<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bocci|first=Cristiano|last2=Chiantini|first2=Luca|date=2013|title=On the identifiability of binary Segre products|url=http://www.ams.org/jag/2013-22-01/S1056-3911-2011-00592-4/|journal=Journal of Algebraic Geometry|volume=22|issue=1|pages=1–11|doi=10.1090/s1056-3911-2011-00592-4|issn=1056-3911}}</ref> and * expected<ref name=":7" /> to be at least two in case 8 with exception of the two identifiable cases <math>F^5 \otimes F^4 \otimes F^3 </math> and <math>F^3 \otimes F^2 \otimes F^2 \otimes F^2 </math>. In summary, the generic tensor of order <math>d > 2 </math> and rank <math display="inline">r < \frac{\Pi}{\Sigma+1} </math> that is not identifiability-unbalanced is expected to be identifiable (modulo the exceptional cases in small spaces).
=== Ill-posedness of the standard approximation problem === The rank approximation problem asks for the rank-<math>r</math> decomposition closest (in the usual Euclidean topology) to some rank-<math>s</math> tensor <math>\mathcal{A}</math>, where <math>r < s</math>. That is, one seeks to solve
: <math> \min_{\mathbf{a}_i^k \in F^{n_k}} \| \mathcal{A} - \sum_{i=1}^{r} \mathbf{a}_i^1 \otimes \mathbf{a}_i^2 \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathbf{a}_i^d \|_F, </math>
where <math>\|\cdot\|_F</math> is the [[Frobenius norm]].
It was shown in a 2008 paper by de Silva and Lim<ref name="dSL2008" /> that the above standard approximation problem may be ''ill-posed''. A solution to aforementioned problem may sometimes not exist because the set over which one optimizes is not closed. As such, a minimizer may not exist, even though an infimum would exist. In particular, it is known that certain so-called ''border tensors'' may be approximated arbitrarily well by a sequence of tensor of rank at most <math>r</math>, even though the limit of the sequence converges to a tensor of rank strictly higher than <math>r</math>. The rank-3 tensor
: <math>\mathcal{A} = \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{v} + \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{v} \otimes \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{v} \otimes \mathbf{u} \otimes \mathbf{u}, \quad \text{with } \|\mathbf{u}\| = \|\mathbf{v}\| = 1 \text{ and } \langle \mathbf{u}, \mathbf{v}\rangle \ne 1</math>
can be approximated arbitrarily well by the following sequence of rank-2 tensors
: <math> \mathcal{A}_n = n (\mathbf{u} + \frac{1}{n} \mathbf{v}) \otimes (\mathbf{u} + \frac{1}{n} \mathbf{v}) \otimes (\mathbf{u} + \frac{1}{n} \mathbf{v}) - n \mathbf{u}\otimes\mathbf{u}\otimes\mathbf{u} </math>
as <math>n \to \infty</math>. This example neatly illustrates the general principle that a sequence of rank-<math>r</math> tensors that converges to a tensor of strictly higher rank needs to admit at least two individual rank-1 terms whose norms become unbounded. Stated formally, whenever a sequence
: <math> \mathcal{A}_n = \sum_{i=1}^r \mathbf{a}^1_{i,n} \otimes \mathbf{a}^2_{i,n} \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathbf{a}^d_{i,n} </math>
has the property that <math>\mathcal{A}_n \to \mathcal{A}</math> (in the Euclidean topology) as <math>n\to\infty</math>, then there should exist at least <math>1 \le i \ne j \le r</math> such that
: <math> \| \mathbf{a}^1_{i,n} \otimes \mathbf{a}^2_{i,n} \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathbf{a}^d_{i,n} \|_F \to \infty \text{ and } \| \mathbf{a}^1_{j,n} \otimes \mathbf{a}^2_{j,n} \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathbf{a}^d_{j,n} \|_F \to \infty</math>
as <math>n\to\infty</math>. This phenomenon is often encountered when attempting to approximate a tensor using numerical optimization algorithms. It is sometimes called the problem of ''diverging components''. It was, in addition, shown that a random low-rank tensor over the reals may not admit a rank-2 approximation with positive probability, leading to the understanding that the ill-posedness problem is an important consideration when employing the tensor rank decomposition.
A common partial solution to the ill-posedness problem consists of imposing an additional inequality constraint that bounds the norm of the individual rank-1 terms by some constant. Other constraints that result in a closed set, and, thus, well-posed optimization problem, include imposing positivity or a bounded [[inner product]] strictly less than unity between the rank-1 terms appearing in the sought decomposition.

== Applications == In machine learning, the CP-decomposition is the central ingredient in learning probabilistic latent variables models via the technique of moment-matching. For example, consider the multi-view model<ref name="anandkumar2014tensor">{{cite journal|last1=Anandkumar|first1=Animashree|last2=Ge|first2=Rong|last3=Hsu|first3=Daniel|last4=Kakade|first4=Sham M|last5=Telgarsky|first5=Matus|title=Tensor decompositions for learning latent variable models|journal=The Journal of Machine Learning Research|volume=15|number=1|pages=2773–2832|year=2014}}</ref> which is a probabilistic latent variable model. In this model, the generation of samples are posited as follows: there exists a hidden random variable that is not observed directly, given which, there are several [[conditionally independent]] random variables known as the different "views" of the hidden variable. For simplicity, assume there are three symmetrical views <math>x</math> of a <math>k</math>-state categorical hidden variable <math>h</math>. Then the empirical third moment of this latent variable model can be written as: <math>T=\sum_{i=1}^{k}Pr(h=i) E[x|h=i]^{\otimes 3}</math>.
In applications such as [[topic modeling]], this can be interpreted as the co-occurrence of words in a document. Then the eigenvalues of this empirical moment tensor can be interpreted as the probability of choosing a specific topic and each column of the factor matrix <math>E[x|h=k]</math> corresponds to probabilities of words in the vocabulary in the corresponding topic.
